Sir:

I beg to inform you that the Church authorities have nominated the Rev. J. Steele Smith for the position as teacher of the Chemawawin Indian Day School for the next school year. Sir,

In reference to letter 128/4/1 of the 25th ult., regard the appointment of Mr. Donald Banks to the position of teacher at the Chemawawin Indian Day School. I beg to state that this gentleman has been in The Pas since November 6th.

I received the telegram from the Department authorizing an advance for transport of Mr. Banks and his wife to the reserve, and this will be attended to when the weather turns colder. The ice on the rivers and lakes is not fit to travel on with dog transport yet, and there are no signs of a cold spell, so Mr. Banks may be held in The Pas for a couple of weeks yet. Sir,

I beg to forward herewith enclosed receipt amounting to $5.97 for expenses incurred in sending a special messenger to Chemawawin to advise the school teacher regarding the school house.

It should be stated that at my visit to the Reserve in October last I found that the school building was beyond repair, and for the safety of human life and Government property I considered it should not be used. The mission buildings were closed, and might be available; but the person in charge of them was Mr. Hines at the Res. This gentleman after some hesitation consented to let two rooms, one for school purposes, the other for Government provisions. In order therefore to keep open the school, there was no other alternative, and as the season was late, it was necessary to inform the Teacher at once. The school is now kept at the mission buildings.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Jackson, in a report to the Department, states that the Chief and Councillors of the Chippewa Reserve at a recent meeting of their council brought up the question of building a new school on that reserve to replace the present old school building.

The band have fifty spruce logs on the ground, twenty-five of them being thirty feet long and twenty-five eighteen feet. This would make a school eighteen by thirty, outside, with a ten foot wall. The Indians wish the Department to assist them in the purchase of the necessary material, such as shingles, window frames, doors, tar paper, lime, etc., and payment of the carpenter work involved. The Inspector forwards an estimate of the material and cost of labour as follows:

- 8000 shingles $60.00
- 34 pieces 2 x 4, 1½ ft $24.00
- 2 windows 12 x 14, 5 lights $5.00
- 2 frames $5.00
- 1000 ft inch boards $40.00
- 200 ft siding $12.00
- 4 rolls tarpaper $6.00
- 200 lbs nails from shingle to 5 in. $14.00
- 10 bushels of lime $5.00
- Wm. Captain, an ex-pupil, will do the carpenter work on the school for $210.00
- If the following tools are furnished him free:
  - 2 claw hammers, 2 handsaws, 1 cross cut saw
  - 1 Jack Plane, 1 smoothing plane, 1 square, 1 level $19.00
- Red paint for roof and paint for inside $50.00
- Freight on material, say $50.00

The Department has considered the request of the Indians favourably and you are hereby authorized to purchase and have delivered on the ground the above quantities at the prices estimated.

You may let the job of erecting the building to William Captain, who has agreed to do the necessary carpentry work for the sum of $220.00. You should give this matter your early attention and have the work started as soon as possible, in order that the building may be finished this fall.

You will be good enough to furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, for the expenditure incurred.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of this work being done and you should purchase the material mentioned by you and have it delivered at the school. Before making the purchase you should obtain competitive prices from a number of firms supplying the lumber and other material required and purchase from the firm quoting you the lowest price. The cost of the material for the closets should not exceed your estimate of $35.00 and that for the lean to for the teacher's house $175.00. The cost of the labour in building the closets should not exceed $10.00 and an allowance of $10.00 to the teacher for doing the work in erecting the lean to. The cost of freighting the material should not exceed your estimate, namely, $7.50 for the closets and $20.00 for the material for the lean to.

You may also purchase the two common chairs required, also the five storm sash windows for the school-house and the cost of the chairs and storm windows should not exceed the estimate furnished by you.

You should forward properly certified accounts, in duplicate, covering the cost of the material, freighting and labour, together with the quotations received by you for the supplying of the building material required. You should give this matter your prompt attention and this work should be completed during the coming summer holidays.

It

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:-

I have your letter of 22nd ultimo relative to the supplies required for a midday meal for the pupils of the Chassawin Indian School.

In reply I beg to say that if you are satisfied that the teacher or his wife will prepare and serve the lunch, you may make the necessary arrangements with them to do so. You may purchase and have delivered the following supplies and equipment:

- 1 large soup kettle
- The necessary quantity of plates, cups, and spoons.

You may also purchase a small quantity of rice and other materials considered necessary in the preparation of the soup. You may also purchase a small quantity of tea or cocoa and a few tins of condensed milk.

It is not intended that an elaborate lunch be furnished each day. This lunch is only intended to supplement the food brought by the children. The Department will rely on you to see that no large or unnecessary expenditure is incurred in the purchase of the supplies required. We will only consent to these meals being furnished the pupils until the end of April next. Properly certified vouchers in duplicate should be forwarded from time to time covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the supplies required for the meals. 500 pounds of biscuit were ordered for this school and these should be used for midday lunch purposes.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of a requisition from the teacher of the Chemawawin Indian Day School for supplies for the use of the school.

It is noted that the teacher requests that a box stove, with the necessary stove pipe, be supplied. If you consider that a new stove is necessary, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of a stove of the type which you consider would be satisfactory to heat the building. You should obtain competitive prices, if possible, and make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price.

It is also noted that the teacher requests that a teacher's desk and chair be supplied. You may obtain prices for the supplying of a teacher's desk similar to that described in the catalogue of the Christie School Supply Co., Brandon, as their No. 10 Sanitary Desk, and for a Teacher's Arm Chair, No. 10, and arrange for the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price.

You may also purchase 80' rope for the flag pole, 2 axe handles, and 1 wash basin.

When the above purchases have been made, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

We are sending you a 6' Union Jack for the use of this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. J. W. WADDY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1927, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE CHEMAWAWIN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

This school requires two closets. They would cost $50 delivered at the school I estimate. The present arrangement they have is not sufficient. This school should be plastered and have the door fixed. The floor is also wearing out, but this will stand a while yet. I do not like to ask for expenditure on this building as they should have a better building there. Then again it looks like poor business to put up a school if the people have to leave the district twice annually to make a living and have no pupils at the school for months. However, I cannot see that we can get away from the expense of plastering it.
Ottawa, June 22nd, 1927.

Sir:

Relative to your report on your inspection of the Chemawawin Indian Day School for the month of June in which you state that two closets are required and that the cost would be approximately $50 delivered at the school, I beg to say that you may arrange to have two closets furnished and placed in a suitable location near the school. You may also arrange to have the door fixed.

After the closets have been installed and the door repaired, you should forward a certified account, in duplicate, in the usual manner covering the cost.

Relative to the plastering required to the school building, I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of having this work done and for any other minor repairs in making this building comfortable. This matter should receive your early attention.

I have also to request that you will state whether you have arranged for the purchase of the teacher's desk and chair as authorized in official letter of April 7th, last.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;-

In reference to letter #128-4-5 of the 6th July last regards plastering the Chemawawin Day School, I beg to report that I could get no plasterer to go down there to do the work, they were afraid to be away from town too long with the poor methods of transport to that place.

Dear Mr. Williams:

I inspected this school on September 20th, 1932. Mr. H. P. Barrett is in charge and has rendered good service, although he is not a qualified teacher. This is an out of the way place, and it would perhaps be more difficult to obtain qualified teachers for this point.

The roll calls for 24 pupils and 23 were present. When the parents are home, the attendance at this school is usually quite good. The grades are arranged as follows:

- Grade I - 10
- Grade II - 6
- Grade III - 8

The children, as you will note, are not very far advanced, but appear to understand the work given them and are not as shy and backward as one might expect. They speak out quite well when questioned and their reading can be heard fairly distinctly.

The building is of log construction, quite large, and in fair repair. It is an old style school with windows on both sides. The building is whitewashed inside and out, and presents a good appearance.

With the present enrolment the school lacks one desk and two seats. Homemade benches are being used at the present time. Biscuits are served as a lunch.

A. S. Williams, Esq.,
Actg. Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Doctor McGill:

I visited this school on March 7th. Mr. H. P. Barrett is the teacher in charge and fair progress is being made. There are 22 on the roll, and the grades are arranged as follows:

- Grade I - 8
- Grade II - 7
- Grade III - 5
- Grade IV - 2

The average attendance for the December quarter was 20.4. The children appeared fairly well along in their grades. They are somewhat shy, due to the fact that they rarely have an outsider visit the reserve. However, they appear to understand when questioned and reply in an intelligent manner. They were somewhat poorly clad, but clean in person and in most cases their hair was neatly combed.

The children receive a lunch at noon, consisting of hot cocoa and biscuits.

The school is a large log building with windows on both sides, but fairly well preserved, and the teacher stated that he found no difficulty in heating it during the cold weather.

The teacher's residence is in good repair, but is badly in need of paint. No decorating has been done.

Extract from report of Mr. Halcrow regarding his survey of the Chemahawin Reserve:

I also examined the school building which is in a very bad state of repair. The building, being old, it would be both expensive and difficult to put it into a state that would be safe and satisfactory as a school room. It could, however, be fixed up to be used as a warehouse for the storage of supplies. I might say it would be quite easy to get logs, located only two miles from the present school, which could be used for the walls of a new school. The Indians could do all this work.
Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 128-4-5, dated the 17th ultimo, in connection with school building for Chemawawin Reserve, Cedar Lake.

This school building is not in the best condition, but it is certainly not the worst one we have got. I have put in the estimates for 1940, a School for Red Earth and this is far more urgently required than one at Cedar Lake.

Lumber could not be taken down there before May, after the river is free from ice.

As regards using the old building for a warehouse, Mrs. Gowans is looking after our issues and drugs on Chemawawin Reserve and she lives quite a distance from the School house. At present the Department's supplies are stored in a warehouse belonging to the Hudson's Bay Co. This is handy and they charge us no rental and the arrangement has proved satisfactory to date.

It was my intention to ask for a school house for the Chemawawin Reserve in the estimate of 1941-42 and I still recommend that that course be adopted. It is almost impossible for me to superintend several buildings being put up in the same year, which are situated a couple of hundred of miles apart and to which travel is difficult.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Extract from Dr. F. Yule's report for the month of March, 1944, on The Pas Agency.

When we reached Cedar Lake we found the teacher and preacher, Rev. Barrett, in school. It so happens that this is the first time I have visited this reserve during the school year. I must confess that both the building and the furniture were a shock to me. The building is not properly lighted and is thirty-five or forty years of age. There were even some broken panes of glass. Several of the seats the children were in were homemade and not suitable.
Ottawa,

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Man.

The Department has recently received Doctor Yule's report in connection with his recent visit to the Chemawawin Day School. In this regard he writes as follows:

"When we reached Cedar Lake we found the teacher and preacher, Rev. Barrett, in school. It so happens that this is the first time I have visited this reserve during the school year. I must confess that both the building and the furniture were a shock to me. The building is not properly lighted and is thirty-five or forty years of age. There were even some broken panes of glass. Several of the seats the children were in were homemade and not suitable."

Please let me know what can be done this summer to improve conditions at this school and at the same time you should let me have an estimate of the expenditure that would be required.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

In reply to your letter dated April 26, 1944, No. I28-4-5. I submit the following report on the schools in The Pas Agency, inspected during the Treaty Payment from June 1st until June 15th.

Cedar Lake School:

Rev. Mr. Barrett is in charge here. He has carried on the work at this point for about fourteen years and is highly respected both by the Indians and whites.

The school attendance is good and the children do nice book work. They were all well dressed and clean. The health was good and the children are apparently well fed.

The school building is past repairing and should be discarded. A new school building is urgently needed. The stove is warped and unsafe. A new one should be provided. New seats and desks are also needed. At present biscuit boxes are used as seats and many of the desks are home-made from rough lumber. The teacher's chair has the back off and this is the only one in the school.

The school residence should be painted both inside and out. No painting has been done to this building for years; in fact, it has not been repainted since it was built many years ago. The foundation is breaking away and it may be necessary to renew this altogether.

Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Extract from Inspector B. Scott Bateman's Report on the Chemawawin School - dated February 19, 1947.

Original on 128-4-6

128-4-5

The building is of log construction and appears quite old. There are no decorations, nor is any attempt made to improve the attractiveness of the school. Although window space is very small (ratio floor area to glass area: 11 : 1) one window has been blocked in with logs and clog. Floors sag badly. School was quite warm and comfortable at time of my visit. Interior and exterior whitewash finish.

There are no outhouses of any kind and children use space behind a large rock about 20 yds. from the school. There are no washing or drinking facilities, and no supply of water is kept in the school. I find this condition to exist in many of the schools in the north. It seems useless to teach principles of cleanliness by word of mouth, but provide none of the facilities necessary to put these principles into action in the classroom. I know that you will make basins, soap, etc. available upon requisition. It might be advisable to call attention to this matter in subsequent issues of the Bulletin.

The blackboards consist of two pieces of cloth 3' x 7', badly checked and glazed.

I know that you will make basins, soap, etc., available upon requisition. It might be advisable to call attention to this matter in subsequent issues of the Bulletin.

The blackboards consist of two pieces of cloth 3' x 7', badly checked and glazed."

The Department approves the expenditure required to build two toilets. You may also purchase wash basins, soap, etc., and you should make certain that proper use of these is made.

We are willing to supply new blackboards for this school and you should state the length and width of the blackboards required.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ration House and School:

When I see these buildings I am not at all proud of our Department. We should set an example and we certainly not doing it here. However, any comments I shall make are purely from a health angle. There has been a lot of rain recently and I discovered that the ration house leaks in places, the plaster has fallen away from between the logs which must allow both rain and snow to penetrate. At one corner the logs are so rotted that the dogs had dug a hole large enough for them to enter and steal some of the bacon. The man has repaired this opening temporarily with tin and stones. Extract from Regional Supervisor Davis' reports dated January 4th on the Chemawawin Indian Day School.

There are 43 children of school age and 15 non-treaty children. We are at present operating a Church of England school at this point. Mr. Taylor, the teacher, is a man of 77 years of age, but very young for his years. The present school is an old log building, falling to pieces and in very poor state of repair. Glass in the windows was broken and the building had not been put in shape at all for the winter. I instructed Mr. Law to see that this work was done at once, so it would be in condition and make it possible for the teacher to carry on if very cold weather came. It would be impossible to hold school in it in its present condition. There is a total population at this point of 80 half-breeds. I would recommend that, if possible, some arrangements be made for a joint school. If it would be possible to have the school operate under the Province it would be more satisfactory - we giving a grant towards the building. If this cannot be done, it will be very necessary that we build a school at this point as soon as possible, as the present old building will not be fit to teach school in for another year. At the time of my visit there were 26 children in the schoolroom and it was very overcrowded. The teacherage is an old building and the property of the Church.
April 23, 1949.

Mr. E. Law,

You have probably received from Mr. Davis the information reports which each superintendent is required to submit concerning his various construction projects for next year. We will expect to receive these from you concerning Chemawawin when its erection can be given further consideration.

Concerning the site Mr. Taylor's recommendation would seem to be satisfactory. You will note that plan 888 does not call for a basement, so we would not have to worry about excavation. I note that you will be checking on this site in the near future.

Memorandum:

SECRET MINISTER,

God's Lake Indian Day School,
Oxford House Indian Day School,
Cheumawin Indian Day School.

The above three schools are included in our building programme for 1949-50. It is our intention to follow the identical plan for these three projects. Due to transportation difficulties, we arranged to ship in, by tractor train during the last winter, complete bills of materials for God's Lake and Oxford House. These materials are now on site ground at the sites selected for these schools.

The materials for Cheumawin, which is on Cedar Lake in The Pas Subdivision, are now being ordered by the Departmental Purchasing Agent and will be shipped by barge from The Pas in the near future.

Mr. Regional Supervisor Davis has been approaching contractors who specialize in construction work in Northern Manitoba. As a result, he has been able to obtain the following labour tenders for the construction of these three schools:

| Contractor          | God's Lake | Oxford House | Cheumawin |
|---------------------|------------|--------------|-----------|
| E. Robison          | $5,000.00  | $6,000.00    | $ -       |
| Matthews Construction Co. | $5,900.00  | $5,900.00    | $5,900.00 |
| Evers Brothers      | $6,800.00  | $6,800.00    | $6,400.00 |

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6230, file 506-5, part 2)
It would seem evident that we can eliminate immediately the highest tenderer, namely Evers Brothers, of Flin Flon, Manitoba.

God's Lake
At God's Lake, Mr. Sebastion's tender is the lowest and I feel it should be accepted. Mr. Davis has some doubts about Mr. Sebastion as a contractor but we have investigated his ability through Indian Health Services. Mr. Sebastion was employed by them last year and I attach a letter from C. J. Connolly, Supervising Engineer, of Indian Health Services, concerning his ability. I would recommend that the Minister approve the acceptance of his Labour Tender for the erection of this school in the amount of $5,000.00.

Oxford House
The lowest of the three tenders is that of the Matthews Construction Company, of The Pas, Manitoba, and I have prepared a draft submission to Council for your consideration. A contract has recently been let with this company for the erection of the Nelson House Indian Day School, by authority of P.C. 347 of May 17.

Chassawarin
The lowest tender for the erection of this school is again that of the Matthews Construction Company of The Pas, Manitoba. Therefore, you will find a joint submission to Council covering both the Oxford House and Chassawarin projects.

Director.

Mr. Elmer Sebastion was employed during our construction work period last summer and fall. He worked at Nelson House both on the nursing station and the erection of your day school. Afterwards he was moved to several places west as far as Driftpile, Alta.

As a carpenter we found his work quite satisfactory and he is capable of being a very good tradesman. I do not have any information of value concerning his integrity as a contractor as he only worked for us on day labour for an hourly wage. TO HIS EXCELLENCY
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1949-50 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, to complete the erection of a new-room Indian Day School on the Chassawin Indian Reserve, in The Pas Indian Agency, in the Province of Manitoba;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Chassawin Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1937, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........";

THAT the building materials for this school are being ordered by the Departmental Purchasing Agent and will be shipped by barge from The Pas to the site of the school in the near future;

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this Indian reserve, there are few builders or contractors in the area, and outside contractors are not interested, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT, as the result of enquiries made by our field officials, we have been able to obtain the following labour tenders for the erection of this building:

Matthews Construction Company, The Pas, $5,900.00
Enzy Brothers, Flin Flon, $6,400.00

THAT the lower tenderer, namely the Matthews Construction Company of The Pas, Manitoba, has building crews in this region and is known to be a satisfactory and reliable contracting firm. This tender covers all transportation and boarding costs and is considered to be fair and reasonable.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the erection of the Chassawin Indian Day School by the Matthews Construction Company of The Pas, Manitoba, at the price of five thousand nine hundred dollars ($5,900.00), this being the most suitable arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried on to completion in order to provide educational facilities for the Indian children on this reserve in time for school opening in September.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

burning heater, instead of a Quebec heater, as I think

I have obtained a Band Resolution for about
two acres of land, suitable for this school and playground.

supply of water. If necessary a well could be tried on
this location at a later date.

the present stove is worn out, and a new one is absolutely
necessary.

possible, so that I can arrange for sand and broken stone
to be delivered to the site. This will be hauled by
barge, but we will have to obtain a wagon to have it
hauled from the shore to the location of the school, as
there is no wagon or any other conveyance which could be
used for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

Re: Chemawawin Indian Day School

The Department finds it necessary to return your Voucher No. 847. You do not state the date of the letter giving authority to you to purchase the wagon. However, in preparing the voucher you refer to hauling gravel for the new school.

As soon as the school is completed, the wagon will be of no use as far as the school is concerned, and consequently, it should not be necessary to pay the whole amount of the account from the appropriation for Indian Education. I presume that when the school is finished the wagon will be used for farm purposes.

You should let us know what portion you consider should be charged to our appropriation.

The Committee of the Privy Council have before them a report dated 4th July, 1949, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

THAT funds are provided in the 1949-50 appropriation, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to construct a one-room Indian Day school and teacher's residence on the Chereswain Indian Reserve, The Pas Indian Agency, Province of Manitoba;

THAT every endeavor has been made to obtain quotations from various firms for the materials required for the building;

THAT it is essential that these materials be purchased at the earliest possible date in order to proceed with the erection of the school;

THAT the Departmental purchasing agent recommends the acceptance of the tender of Dominion Lumber and Fuel Company Limited, Winnipeg, Manitoba to supply the lumber and millwork (for a total cost of $6,635.63 F.o.b. Winnipeg, Manitoba) deliver to commence immediately.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Honorable the Minister of Mines and Resources, that authority be granted for the acceptance of the tender of Dominion Lumber and Fuel Company Limited to supply the materials on which they have quoted at a price of $5,618.63 which plus contingencies will involve an expenditure of approximately $6,500.00.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of Department letter of December 16th, 1949 requesting Progress Report on the construction of the above mentioned school.

Yesterday I forwarded the following telegram:

"Forwarding final progress report re Chemawawin Indian Day School. I am withholding $500.00 from final payment until building completed satisfactorily."

I am enclosing Progress Payment Report No. 4 and have altered same to read $900.00 instead of $1400.00. The reason for holding back $500.00 of final payment is that last week I visited Cedar Lake and inspected this school and I am not satisfied with finishing work to the interior, the whole interior has been painted white instead of colours shipped and there are still two windows with frames to be set in. Also there is poor joining in several instances which I think should be corrected before paying total of final payment.

I do not believe that it will be possible to have the work on this building completed to my satisfaction before the end of the fiscal year, and would be obliged if you would advise how this will effect appropriation already made for the construction of this school.

Dear Mr Scott,

May I direct your attention once more to the need of a teachers house at Cedar Lake reserve. There is a small log house there at the present time which has been used by the last Indian teacher and it is not fit for any self respecting white teacher to live in.

Sir;-

In reference to letter 128-4-8 of the 9th inst, regards residence for teacher at Chemawawin Reserve, I beg to say I took up part of this question in my letter #4064-105 written on the 8th inst.

The situation at Chemawawin is that the Church has a house there which is uninhabitable, and the Department has a small two roomed shack formerly used by Mr. J.G.Kennedy. I can understand that there is a complaint regards vermin in this place, as when I wrote letter #2538-105 on March 12th last, recommending discharge of the teacher, I had just got through a thorough disinfecting of my own person from the lice I had collected in the house at Chemawawin while visiting there a few days previous. If it was only a matter of vermin the place could be renovated and cleaned, but the old shack is really not fit for a residence.

The prospect for pupils is fair, the teacher should have 20 on the roll shortly. I have a good opinion of the new teacher, he is a smart chap, with a wife who wants to settle down for a time. I think if a house is built for him he will remain some years with the Department.

A house could be put up for about $1600.00 including freight I estimate. There is no carpenter in the locality of Chemawawin, one or two would have to be sent down to do the work, unless the Department saw fit to give a contract for the work. There are so many ways in which carpenters can run up expense on a job when they are out of sight that in my opinion it would be well to consider a contractor to do the work. This would be a frame building.

Sir:

I have to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan has secured Mr. and Mrs. Banks for the Chemawawin Indian Day School. Re- School House, Cedar Lake.

With the new school opened at Cedar Lake with living quarters attached, we would like to have your opinion regarding the old teacherage.

This house I believe is owned by your Department but furnished by the Church. It is adjacent to the Church and it would appear important that it should be retained in case we should have a Missionary there in addition to a teacher. Further it is the only place available for Episcopal and Diocesan visitors to stay--this may also apply to treaty parties etc.

Would it be possible for us to buy the house and we can then maintain it as a furnished centre, used by the missionary if required and available for official visitors. If this suggestion is feasible perhaps you could advise me as to the price the government would put on the building.

Yours sincerely,

Archdeacon of Brandon.

Ottawa, February 13, 1936.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, regarding the seasonal day school at Churchill. In this connection it is noted that you intend to commence teaching services about April 15th, next. You have not stated the length of time the school will be in operation. Last summer, it is noted, it was conducted for a two month period.

The Department will continue the grant for salary at the same rate as was allowed last year, viz.: $80.00 per teaching month, for a period not to exceed four months. This will be paid upon receipt of returns, showing attendance, days taught, etc. On the return, you should state definitely the date the school opened and also the date it was closed for the summer.

It is noted that a regular full-time school would meet with little success, as the parents remain at Churchill only during the summer months. It is noted, further, that the classroom activities will be conducted in the back portion of your church and that you, personally, have made desks and necessary equipment. The Department will be prepared to supply a reasonable quantity of classroom materials, such as texts, scribblers, pencils, etc., upon receipt of a requisition from you, regarding the supplies of this nature required.

Right Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th instant the Department approves the appointment of Rev. R.T. Gibson as teacher at Churchill. Payment will be allowed him at the rate of $80.00 a teaching month.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th inst., No.11875, referring to the Indian school at Cross Lake. Having learned in the earlier part of the winter that the school was without a qualified teacher, Mr Joblin, the teacher at Norway House Boarding School, was sent as a temporary supply; his place being filled by another member of the staff. Subsequently another qualified teacher was secured, and he was sent to Cross Lake, Mr Joblin returning to his work at Norway House. I hope that this last appointment will prove to be permanent, and that there will be no further interruptions of the school work.

I have reason to believe that the report concerning the school building is correct, and it is very desirable that the building should be thoroughly repaired, or, which would be still better, a new school house erected. We have given authority for the erection of a new place of worship, and will be glad to co-operate with the Department in any practicable way to put the whole property in such a shape that it may be a useful object lesson to the Indians. The work of the new church will be undertaken as soon as we can find a suitable person who can go in and supervise the construction, and
perhaps it might be practicable for the Department to take action respecting the school building at the same time.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

A. Sutherland

Sir,

I enclose a copy of school report for year ending December 31st, 1912, from Miss Cunningham, school teacher of the Methodist Day School at Cross Lake.

In her report she mentions the great need of a Black-board; in a previous letter I mentioned the unsuitability of the material purchased in Winnipeg last summer for Black-Boards and sent here. The material that I have here for Black-Boards is stiff and solid, making it unsuitable for shipment.

The class of material required for distant schools should be what is called Black-Board cloth, which rolls up and can be shipped to these distant schools in a small and handy package so that it will arrive at its destination in perfect order and condition. The material I have here cannot be shipped without being badly damaged in transit; it will do very well for the day schools in the immediate vicinity of the Agency here.

In a letter recently received from Miss Cunningham, school teacher at Cross Lake, she has made application to me to teach school in July for 16 days during holidays in order to make up her full teaching time.

Now there is this to be said about it, Miss Cunningham is taking a great deal of pains in educating these children, and she feels that as the children had an extended holiday last fall before she could get out, she thinks that it would not hurt them to come to school during the month of July, provided that she gets the consent of the Chief and Band and also the consent of the Department.

On the other hand the children, I expect will want their holidays at the usual time, and I suppose they would take the stand that it was up to the teacher to have been out at the proper time to open school last fall on the 1st of September. I am of the opinion that it will not hurt these children to go to school in July as they lose lots of time during the winter through cold weather and storms.

I would therefore recommend Miss Cunningham's application to teach the number of days in July that she wishes to.

Sir,

During my official visit to Split Lake and on my arrival at Croce Lake, I was requested by the Chief and part of his Band to attend a council meeting to be held in the school house on Monday the 25th of January. Accordingly attended the meeting both Revd Mr Gaudin and Father Thomas being present.

The first subject gone into was "Destitution". Chief Peter Rose then spoke for his Band and explained to me how hard it was for them to make a living this winter with prices for fur so low and no labour of any account to be had. I pointed out to him and those assembled, that if they had only been diligent and energetic at their hunting operations and fishing, they would not have had any destitution amongst the Band. I told them how I had seen portions of his Band along the road to Split Lake and how these Indians were making their living, and that they were above all want and doing well. It was merely that some of his Band that were lazy and shiftless, and they had listened to vague reports scattered about the country by irresponsible parties, that the Government were going to assist them as the prices for fur had gone so low, that probably they would suffer by it. I told them they should have exerted themselves even more than ever, and made good hunts, as I knew that the traders round his reserve were paying fair prices for their fur and paying a great deal more than the H.B. Company, and that those who did not hunt could have had labour at either Mission, if they so wished it. They were the ones to blame for listening to these stories and for letting themselves get poor, and I told them the Department did not propose to assist any one.
who was lazy and any among them that did not work or make an effort and a strong effort to work or hunt, that they need not expect assistance. The Department would probably assist those who were sick or disabled from some accident, as it would be very likely that they might require assistance, but to any able bodied man, no assistance would be given, unless he could prove to the satisfaction of the Police or the Missionaries, that he had been hunting, and had made a failure, then probably a little assistance would be given in a case of that kind, to enable that man to make another effort in his hunting operations. But they were to make up their minds that no man able to work or hunt would receive any assistance whatever. The people at the meeting then promised that they would try and hunt or look for work.

Re New School/

This question has come up again, they want a new day school, that is the Protestant part of the Band. A few years ago before my appointment as Agent, a new school was then to be built and logs had been cut and hauled to the reserve, lumber had been bought and sent to Cross Lake in care of the Hudson's Bay Company. Since I came to Norway House I have repeatedly asked some of the residents to put up those logs and commence the building, but no one seemed to care to take on the job, as I hear the logs cut and paid for were not large enough for a school of the size that they wish to have built now. The Revd Mr Wright who took up the duties of teacher for the Cross Lake school this year has had such a favourable turn out of scholars that the Revd Mr Gaudin and the Methodist portion of the Indians have decided to request the Department to build them a day school on a larger scale than was proposed some years ago by the Revd Mr Semmens, Inspector of Indian Agencies. The size of the building then estimated, was to be 25 ft x 20 ft with a 9 ft wall, this building was to have been erected by Mr McIvor of Cross Lake, as I can see by the correspondence, but was never done.
I asked Mr. McIvor to have it done and he said he would do it, if he could get men, in this he failed. I tried another man, Macdonald by name, and he was going to do it, but he also failed to come up to time, live fox hunting being more lucrative. I then asked Mr. Gaudin to get men and superintend it himself; this he said he would do, but unfortunately Mr. Gaudin took ill and went to Winnipeg to undergo an operation, this of course obliged Mr. Gaudin to give it up, as it was very late in the season before Mr. Gaudin arrived home.

The old school house has been in such bad condition for some years now, (it is 25 years old) that I found it necessary to allow Mr. Gaudin to rent a house to be used for the purpose of a school house for the winter term. This house belongs to Councillor Thomas Ross and seats about 40 children, although a little crowded. I saw the councillor and asked him what rent he would take and he replied $4.00 a month. I think this is reasonable and I told him that I would recommend that he be paid this rent for his house. The councillor is a cripple and has a blind son to support, and I think a small sum like this would enable the councillor to buy clothing for his blind son who is a man and also for the rest of his family. Mr. Gaudin generously assists this family in any way that he can, but cannot altogether support him.

The new school that is proposed to be built and which is requested of the Department, is planned as follows:

School building to be built of logs, 36 ft x 22 ft.
Porch to building " " " 8" x 8".
5 Windows, 16 x 24, most of these windows ought to be stored at Cross Lake.
2 Doors, one for main building and one for Porch. 6 ft x 3 ft.
Wall of building to be 5 ft 6 in. high.

Most of the old logs could be used on the ends, the sides, 36 ft long would have to be secured. Lumber would also have to be bought. This I think could be saved up at the
the Roman Catholic saw mill, if the Indians would cut the logs and have them taken to the mill where I dare say the Brothers in charge of the mill would saw the logs into lumber. The doors and windows that were secured for the first building were put into the agency warehouse which has been used as a hospital until this winter when I had the I.W. supplies stored there.

In looking into the correspondence on the Cross Lake school building, I find that 15 rolls of roof feltting, 1 door, 6 windows, and 3000 feet of flooring were shipped to Cross Lake four years ago, and about 300 feet of rough lumber was sent down by York boat. It will be seen if a new building of the size they are asking for now, would require quite a lot more rough lumber to complete the building. Making a rough calculation of the roof, gable ends, bottom flooring, and porch, it would take in the neighborhood of 2,500 feet of rough lumber to complete the building.

Providing the Indians would secure the logs and have them sawed up at the Catholic sawmill, the cost of sawing would be $20.00 at the rate of $4.00 a thousand feet. This would be a great deal cheaper than freighting lumber from Selkirk, which would probably cost 40 or 45 dollars a thousand feet to land it at Cross Lake.

There is no doubt that a school house of this size should be built, as Mr. Wright had 44 children on the register in his December report attending school. To seat this many children would require a few more desks as they have almost enough to do at the present. Their old equipment is in a fair condition, some of the ink pots being missing only. With part of a new school outfit and a new school they would be quite up to date in so far as reserve day schools go.

Dear Sir,

By the kind permission of Dr. Norquay, Indian agent, I am to tell you something of the needs of our Indians on this reserve.

I came last October to teach school, but we had to close school on December ninth because of epidemic influenza. Since that date, Mrs. Sandin, field matron, has been confined to her room, leaving the work of visiting Indian homes in that capacity to me for a time.
Hence you will understand that I speak of conditions with which I am in touch, and from different sides.

These Indians are ill-nourished and underfed; not wholly because they have no food, for the missionary, Rev. S.D. Gaudin, gives supplies to the destitute each week, but they waste what is given by ill cooking.

One instance, out of many which might be cited, will suffice to illustrate. When visiting a very sick patient I asked to have some rolled oats cooked for him. It was immediately stirred into some boiling water on the stove. A few moments later, as I had turned to examine another patient, his wife had poured the mixture into a plate and was about to feed...
Inquiry revealed that this was their usual way of serving rolled oats. It is probable that if these people had been taught to cook as children, the women would have known how to feed her family and the man would not have died, as he did, next day.

The Indian children whom I have taught to cook have been much interested in the art, and have practiced it in their homes, the parents seeming pleased to have them cook like white people. Also this work has been a strong incentive to their using English.

As there is to be a schoolhouse built on this reserve next year would it be possible, sir, to have a section partitioned
for teaching cooking?

The government would soon make up the cost—putting in a room and equipment, because the provisions given out would last so much longer in the homes of the school children.

I understand that the biscuits which are provided by the government, to be given morning and afternoon to supplement home meals, are the only nourishment these children have at midday (our custom is to give the two at noon) and that frequently they have but one other meal. With a cooking class we would, by use of a few plain provisions, serve a simple meal.
cooked by themselves each noon.

One peculiarity of the people here is that they like to have their children come to school when very young. Perhaps the biscuits attract them, but they do attend with fair regularity at the age of six. We need a kindergarten, so they could be taken in a year younger—in time to learn a small vocabulary of English and to get rid of their thieving propensities, so that at the age of seven they would be really ready to enter a primary grade.

This plan would call for two teachers, a kindergartner, a directress who would also teach cooking, and a primary teacher. The building required would be little larger than that proposed.
already, but it would meet real needs of these people, while a mere ordinary schoolroom has proven far from adequate.

The upper storey would be divided into kindergarten and kitchen, while schoolroom and storeroom would occupy the ground floor.

There are in most urgent need of a hospital here; and we are in just as great need of a school building where the children may be taught food values and preparation, sewing and mending etc as well as to know something about the three R's.

I wish to thank you, sir, beforehand, for the consideration you always show & suggestions for Indians welfare: and to beg you will do all you can for these Indians. Very Respectfully Yours

Sir,

Replying to Department letter No. 116275/1 dated May 20th, regarding a joint school for Indians and whites at Cross Lake, I beg to say that Commissioner Wallace asked my opinion regarding this matter last winter while here. He said that there were not enough white children at Cross Lake to warrant the Provincial Government building a school, and if the Department of Indian Affairs would build a school, the Provincial Government would co-operate, by providing a grant, towards the teacher's salary. I fell in with his views on the matter, and wrote the Department accordingly.

I have looked over the material which was sent to Cross Lake for the purpose of building the proposed school, and find that very little of it is of any use. There is some sheathing, probably 1000 ft. I did not measure it but roughly estimated it. Practically all the material for a building would have to be sent out.

As to the size of building, I would suggest a building 40x22 feet with a 10 foot wall. Of this to construct a main class room 32x22. The remaining 8x22 to be equally divided for cloak rooms, for boys and girls. Have two entrance doors, one for boys and another for the girls. This would necessitate two more doors from the cloak rooms into the class room.

The windows should be all on one side of the building, and there should be six, to give good light; with two more in front of building to light the cloak rooms. The side opposite from the windows would be used for blackboard, and for hanging maps.

A raised platform 14x6 should be for the teacher's desk. On either side of this could be built cupboards for the storing of school material. The chimney should be built from the cloak rooms to the roof, and the stove placed in the centre of the class room. The pipes would thus assist in heating the building. Two rows of double desks would be placed down either side of the building, and a row of the same kind in the centre fore and aft the stove. I think there would be ample room to seat from forty to fifty children.

If a school of the size I have suggested is built, the logs taken out by the Indians will not do. In any case a frame building would be better, as it is not possible to get logs of any size in this rocky country.
I would not advise shipping the material this season, as the season is so far advanced now. If it is decided to build the school, the supplies could be purchased and delivered at Selkirk, and an understanding made with the Northern Fish Co. to bring it out on the first boat coming out in the spring of 1921. Of course the building be let by contract, which would be better; it would be up to the contractor to get the building material out.

By waiting for another year, we could see how the Indians view the situation re the attendance of their children to school. I shall talk to them very plainly at the treaty payments and tell them it is up to them whether they get a school or not. I am getting the chief interested in the education of the children of his band, and as I suggested the appointment of Miss Christina McLeod to succeed Miss Richardson, she will be the figure she might work up good attendance. We don't want any more teachers of Miss Richardson's stamp. She couldn't teach. She had no influence over the children nor the Indians. Miss McLeod is a Methodist, and has a good college education.

I am enclosing a rough ground plan in pencil which will give an idea of what I have explained in this letter.

Dear Sir:

May I present my side of the case, relative to my position as teacher of the Indian Day School at Cross Lake, Manitoba? We are so isolated up here at these northern outposts that there is no one else to speak for me.

There are only two white families at Cross Lake, those of the Hudson Bay man and the missionary. The latter, because the school is called the United Church Indian Day School, assumes a little like control of the affairs of the school when there is no work attached to them, so that the teacher can't call her mind her own.

I boarded at the missionary's home for one month and because I chose to live by myself as the other teacher did before me, during the last two years she was at Cross Lake, I have been the victim of a consistent vindictiveness on the part of the missionary, culminating in a whispering campaign during June with the Indian Agent and Head of the Church, with the result that I was refused nomination for the coming year of 1935-36.
The local and controlling authorities have no other source of information except the missionary and take whatever he says as the basis of their opinions. I applied in the spring for the school and received a very favorable reply from Mr. Beaton. But after his visit to Norway House in June, where he talked with the missionary and the agent, it was simply a case of thumbs down.

The missionary's wife has the field matron's job and she has a daughter just out of Normal School that he wants to get a position for. The Family Compact of historical fame has nothing on what is going on at Cross Lake. When the missionary gets his daughter in, they will have all the positions there are to be had at Cross Lake. The obvious way to accomplish this is to create a vacancy and the nomination of his daughter will follow.

The missionary maintains his daughter needs a position. Well maybe she does, but she doesn't need it any more than I do, as I support my seventy-year-old mother and a fifteen-year-old daughter, whom I...
am sending through High School and later through University.

The missionary at Cross Lake is W.W. Shoup who lost his position as principal of the Norway House Industrial School last year, on account of his use of penitentiary methods of punishment of the Indian children there. I was a member of the staff at Norway House Industrial School that reported on the condition of affairs and know whereof I speak, as I was an eye-witness of the atrocities. This also is another reason why he is against me.

Mr. Beaton got the impression in Norway House this June, and told it in Winnipeg, that my work as teacher in Norway House was a failure. He got that from Mr. Shoup it is untrue, in proof of which I would respectfully refer you to the Public School Inspector's report which is on your file, and to the enclosed copy of a statement concerning my work, and written by W.W. Shoup at the close of my work there.
If the impression, that my work was a failure at Norway House came from the Agent, I would respectfully call your attention to the fact that the Agent just came to Norway House in Oct 1935, and that he was not in Norway House at the time I was teaching there and therefore his opinion is only based on hearsay and not on actual observation.

If the Agent got his impression from the teacher who took my place, she had never taught junior work before and has not had enough experience to be able to pass judgment on another teacher's work.

It might clarify your idea of the situation if I gave a resume of the work done at Cross Lake.

I arrived at Cross Lake on Saturday, Sept. 1st, 1935, after a four day's journey by canoe via the Hudson Bay Railway, making running landings, portaging, and lining the canoe trip rapids of the swirling rushing waters of the Nelson River. My brother is a Forest Ranger and took me in.
I went and saw the school the first day I landed there. I explained why I was on the journey in, and was unable to start school the first week and asked Mr. Shoup to go over to the school and put up a notice that school would begin the following week. He did so, as well as removing the school viola which I had seen at school on the first day of my arrival there. He took it to his home giving out the information through his children, that it was mission property. I naturally believed this. At Christmas I asked for the loan of it for the Christmas concert, and it was broken. I then learned that the viola had been purchased and donated to the school by a former teacher, Miss Macgill, and that my predecessor had spent Five Dollars ($5.00) on repair work and a new spring for it. Also that a former missionary had requested my predecessor to remove it from the mission when she left as it was not mission property. I might say that Mr. Shoup still has the school viola.
I could not help feeling that if an Indian had entered the school and removed the victoria, he would have been up before the authorities for stealing, but when the missionary could do it and get away with it, in an out of the way place, it was alright.

I was making a coat for a little girl at school, and Mr. Shoup just to shut my eyes to conditions at Cross Lake. I thought to myself that I did not come up here to shut my eyes, but to help the Indians. It seemed to me that the missionary's aims and ideas were diametrically opposed to mine and the sooner we went our separate ways the better.

After we got started going to school, we were always fifteen minutes to a quarter of an hour late. I spoke nicely to Mr. Shoup about it asking if we couldn't leave at 8:30 or the latest 8:45 so I could start school at 9:00 o'clock. He was very snappy and replied that he didn't want his children on the Reserve a minute longer than they had to be, and if...
I didn't like the way things were; I had better make other arrangements.

It turned very cold in Sept. and I asked Mr. Shoup to assist in getting some wood for the school. As nothing was done I began making inquiries and found that the agent had delegated the Hudson Bay man to get the school wood, and we soon had wood at the school.

I noticed in the register that it was recorded that school had to be dismissed on very cold days because it was impossible to get the school warm enough for the children.

The teacher who preceded me had warned me to get the school building banked with earth in Sept. as the school was very cold. I asked Mr. Shoup to assist me with that but got no co-operation or help whatever.

We had snow the third week in Sept. and the school building was very cold. The wind blew through it the same as if it were only a shed. I was writing on the blackboard.
and the wind was just pouring down on my head. I climbed up to the attic on the top ledge of a window and through a two foot square hole to see where the wind came from and found the top of the building in a very unfinished condition. There were gaps between the logs big enough to thrust my hand and arm right through outdoors. The windows did not fit the window frames and were only partly put in place, leaving gaps from one to two inches at the sides and top.

Downstairs the windows, which were all along one side of the school room, had no finishing outside at all and the former teacher had pasted brown paper over the cracks to keep the wind out. The beaver board had great holes in it where wood had been piled; and since the quarter round had been omitted the floor was extremely cold.

Outside the logs had been covered by siding to the gables and shingles had been used above that. The space between the siding and the shingles was left unfinished so that
Cross Lake, Man.

9.

an opening of from four to six inches was left where the wind and snow blew in at will through the loose and cracks making the school very cold.

I saw that there was an immediate need to put the school into shape so that it would be fit to hold school in when the temperature sank to 40 below. That the school was very much in need of being fixed up, is substantiated by the fact that it is undergoing extensive repairs this summer.

I asked Mr. Shoup to help but he said it was the business of the Chief. The Chief lived a long way across a bay and I had no way of getting over there. It was necessary to cross the river to reach the school. I asked for the boat to cross on Saturday but never could get it. Winter was imminent; it was almost the 1st of Oct. with freeze-up due any time between the 1st and the 15th; the need of repair was great and I got no help, so I concluded the only way I could get it done was to go over and stay in the school building and superintend the work myself. The agency was sixty miles away and can't be...
reached only by canoe, by two days paddling or one day with an engine and the agent comes only once during the school year in March. Moreover, we heard that the agent had left and that a new agent would come in, in Oct. There wasn't time to write the agent and get an answer before the frost came and it would be impossible to fill the cracks with any mixture when it was freezing or to dig earth for the banking.

On Oct 4th I went over to stay at the school and carried out the following repairs. I found a half a bag of cement upstairs in the school. I hired a workman, although I had great difficulty as almost every man on the Reserve had gone off on the Fall Fishing Trip to provide food for their dogs for the winter just preceding freeze up; at the time when the weather is cool enough so the fish won't spoil and before the lakes and rivers are frozen.

I had a mixture made of lime, sand, and cement and the cracks between the logs upstairs filled up and also the cracks around the windows downstairs.
Moss from the muskeg was used in cracks where the cement mixture could not be used. Upstairs the windows were fitted properly; the foundation of the school was banked. There were two huge holes where the dogs used to get under the school and howl, and we couldn't get them out. A ladder was made and put in place so one could get to the attic without risking one's neck and so that extra books and supplies could be safely placed there. Glass was put in one window and the rest puttied. This work was completed before freeze-up.

Although Mr. Shoup had previously taken no interest in the school he immediately became very much interested when I made a move to do things myself. He wrote the agent that I had gone over to the school which was unfit for occupation, and there was great danger of me burning the school down. The new agent had just arrived and wrote me to vacate, which I did the next day, having completed my work at the school.

I moved on Friday night into a house without a roof or a floor, which at one time had been occupied by my predecessor. On Saturday I had the roof...
put on and the floor fixed, also the inside lined with building paper. During the next week I had the cracks between the logs filled with clay, and white washed. Mr. Shoup told the owner of the house he had no business to rent me a house. Mr. Shoup would never have taken the trouble to write the agent only he was trying to force me to return to his house and when I did not do so he used all the influence he could against me although I taught his daughters music, and put the elder one through Grade VIII when I had my hands full teaching the Indian children without any white children.

I never missed a day of school after I started to teach. On Sundays I helped with the playing & singing at church and trained a quartette to sing at special services. I have won the confidence and respect of the Indian people and as soon as they heard I was leaving the Chief & Councillors came to me and said they wanted me to stay and that they were going to send a letter on my behalf which may have reached you.

When I used to run up the flag in the morning I thought, "Canada is a free country, and the British flag stands for justice, but because I'm off in this isolated place I don't get a square deal." I am appealing to you to give me a chance to remain until the Pub. School Inspector from the Dept. of Ed. Winnipeg or Inspector Hamilton from the Dept. of Ind. Affairs has a chance to pass judgment on my work at Cross Lake and dwell (over)
stand or fall by their statements; I have done the best I could under the circumstances, and it does not seem fair that I should lose my position through the spite work of the missionary.

I have the honour to be,
your obedient servant,
Mrs. Grace Savage.

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 28th February, I inspected the Cross Lake United Church Indian Day School.

The register was marked up to date. There were 37 pupils enrolled, six of whom were non-treaty children.

At the time of my visit, there were 25 pupils present, and all were clean and tidy.

The pupils' reading, and book work were fair. The discipline also was fair.

The average attendance was good for the past two months, and both teacher and pupils showed considerable interest in their work.

There were not sufficient desks to accommodate all the pupils; six of them using biscuit boxes as seats and desks. There are however, enough desks for the Indian pupils.

Since my last visit to this school, the school building has been repaired very considerably, but there is still a little more to do. With the warmer weather comes, such as the building of the new chimney, and the painting of the outside of the building, which was held up last fall by the cold. The inside of the school walls has been painted, and is greatly improved. A new heater stove has been installed.

It was the intention to erect a tower for the school bell, but on examining the bell, it was found that a part of it was missing, so some other arrangement will be made for hanging it.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lamenby,
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to report that on January 31st, I visited and inspected the Cross Lake U.C. Indian Day School.

The building in which this school is now operated, has been remodelled from a warehouse belonging to the United Church, and a very good job has been done. The school is well finished inside and bright. The new desks and other furnishings have so far been very well taken care of. Pupils were all clean and well dressed.

The register was marked up to date, and contained the names of thirty Treaty Indian pupils and eleven non-treaty pupils. At the time of my visit, there were 27 pupils present consisting of 17 Indians and 10 non-treaty pupils. 8 more beginners had started attending the school two weeks previous to my visit. The aggregate attendance for the week ending January 29th was 111, whereas the aggregate attendance for the corresponding week, the previous year, was 68.

Reading done by pupils of grades 3 and 4 was fairly good, but the reading done by pupils of grade 1 was very poor. The reason for this seemed to be that the teacher was endeavoring to teach the pupils to read by sentences, instead of by words. He would write a sentence on the board, and after telling them what it was made them repeat it, but when I asked any pupil to identify any single word in that sentence he could not do it.

During recess the teacher discussed this matter with me, and said he had never taught reading in this manner before, but that he was trying it on instructions from the missionary, Mr H. Meadows. I then asked him if he was making any headway.
with this method, and he said he did not seem to be. While talking the matter over in the evening, Mr Meadows stated that this was the new method being used at the Universities in the teaching of languages. Personally I can see no sense in it, as applied to Indian children.

The teacher has heretofore not been doing much in the way of having pupils work at the blackboard, but thinks he will do more of this in the future.

The teacher, Mr Gerbrandt, is keenly interested in his work, and if a pupil is absent for more than a day or two he visits the home to find out the reason. He is well liked by all the Indians and tries to make the school so interesting that the pupils want to come. I think he will do well.

F. G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.
United Church Mission
Cross Lake, Man.

H. A. Meadows, B.A. - Missionary

Dear Sirs,

The attendance at the Indian Day School operated by this mission is much larger this year than it has been for many years. This mainly due to the fact the school which is being held in one of our mission buildings is more easily accessible to a larger number of children than it was on the old site.

Some of the Indians are anxious that when the school is re-built it will be located on the old site which is their "Treaty Grounds", losing sight of the fact that in the old location it cannot serve as many children as can be served in other locations. There has been a tendency in the past on the part of missionaries to have the Indian school built on mission property or near mission property. While this may make for an imposing row of buildings it often does not serve the needs of the majority of the children. I believe that when the school is re-built, care should be taken to locate the school where it can serve the majority of the children.

Located as the old school was on the "Treaty Grounds" it was at about the centre of the Reserve and this was good. But this is the older part of the settlement and the people living in this area are mostly older people without school-age children. Neither is our mission property the best location although it is better than the old one as I have stated; and it is not on the reserve.

If the Department would care to have me do so I am prepared to make a survey of the reserve to ascertain the areas highest in child population and areas potentially high i.e., areas where there are young married couples building new homes. The children below school-age at present would have to be considered also as it will indicate the future usefulness of a school in a particular area.

If the Department cares to have me do this and will supply me with a few maps of the reserve on which I can indicate the population areas and indicate possible sites for a school or schools I shall be glad to carry out this project. I am,

Yours truly,

H. A. Meadows

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept' of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose Monthly Attendance Return for the Cross Lake U.C. Day School. I inspected this school on 6 December. There were 33 pupils present and the building was badly overcrowded. According to Provincial Health Regulations this building should only accommodate about 20 pupils and they have had as many as 50 in it. No action can be taken against absentees under Sec 4 Subsection 2 Family Allowances Act as there are enough U.C. children in this community to fill 3 day schools and at present there is only accommodation for 20.

Mr McKee the teacher is doing good work under trying circumstances. The building is neat and clean and the children look neat and clean and there is a considerable improvement in this school comparing it with last year.

There is a cross light in the school, the blackboard is old and made of cloth and no child in the body of the school can see anything on it. A new blackboard space is urgently needed and I have instructed Mr McKee to requisition for one.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

On Saturday, we received the following telegram from Rev. Ian Harvey, our Missionary on the Cross Lake Indian Reserve:

"Catholic Priest has requested time and use of classroom at our new day school for purpose of religious instruction for Catholic children attending there stop Teacher granted same but I have overridden her pending orders from you stop Copy of letter sent to Father in mail for you and Doctor Best stop Would appreciate prompt reply."

As Dr. Dorey was in Western Canada, I relayed the wire to him at Edmonton. He has wired back, requesting that I send you a copy of Mr. Harvey's wire and ask for a ruling from you.

This morning we received a letter, by air mail, from Mr. Harvey, enclosing copy of a communication he had sent to the Rev. Fr. Trudeau, St. Joseph's I.R.S., Cross Lake. In this letter, Mr. Harvey has requested Father Trudeau to refrain from conducting classes until he gets advice from headquarters.

We shall appreciate it greatly if you will give this matter your immediate attention and send us a reply, indicating what steps should be taken in such a situation as this.

I should add that in his communication, Mr. Harvey states that he feels that the teacher has over-stepped her responsibility in granting permission for the conducting of these classes, and that he feels rather strongly that it is unfair that the Roman Catholic Priest should have the right to use these facilities for religious purposes. I shall quote a few sentences from his letter to Father Trudeau:

"Personally, I would be against your being given such a right, simply because it would be so utterly illogical to grant it to you. If Indian schools were non-denominational, it would be different. Then I would be among the first to defend your right to equal treatment with myself. But so long as they remain under the churches (as your church, not ours, insists that they remain) just so long do I feel that it must be a case..."
of you-stay-in-your-schools-and-I'll-stay-in-mine. We're glad to take your children in if it will help fill in till your new school is built; but we cannot, by doing so, give up our right to keeping our school a United Church school, just as you keep yours Roman Catholic to the core."

Yours sincerely,

Dear Dr. Macdonald:

Re: Cross Lake Indian Day School -

I have for acknowledgment your letter of March 15th, in which you submit for departmental consideration the request of the Reverend Father Trudeau for permission to provide religious instruction to the Catholic pupils attending the Cross Lake Indian Day School.

Inasmuch as this is the first request of its kind that has reached me since I entered the department twelve years ago, I feel that it is one that should be very carefully reviewed and considered before a decision is reached.

May I point out, however, that a number of mistakes appear to have been made. The school in question is the property of the Crown, and any request for its use, such as the request of Father Trudeau or any other request for the use of the school for extra-curricular activities, should be submitted to the senior administrative officer in the district, which in this case is the Indian Agent at Norway House, Mr. E. B. Goodman. If this had been done in the first instance, it is altogether likely that Mr. Goodman would have discussed the matter with the members of the Indian Council and, having done so, would have forwarded the request to this branch for consideration. Had he done so, the matter would have been in due course referred to the Minister for his decision. It is always in the interests of our Indian Agents, school teachers and may I add, missionaries engaged in missionary effort on Indian reserves, to refer all such matters to the department. Such action on their part tends to keep friction and misunderstandings down to the irreducible

-- 2
minimum. It is my intention, therefore, to refer this matter to the Indian Agent, asking him to submit a full and complete report, together with his recommendations.

You are aware, of course, that a Special Parliamentary Committee is at present engaged in a review of Indian administration in Canada. The sections in the Act relating to the education of Indians are at the moment under consideration. What amendments will be made to these sections, I am not of course at the moment in a position to state. I do feel, however, that a number of the sections relating to religious instruction, the employment of teachers, etc., will be greatly clarified.

Yours sincerely,

I have for acknowledgment your letter of
March 17, 1948 re Cross Lake Indian Day School and Religious
Education, and enclosures.

I am to blame for this whole situation and
no-one else. On a visit to Cross Lake on March 5 I stopped
off first at the Catholic Mission and Father Trudeau in-
formed me that quite a number of Catholic children were
attending the new U.C. School at Cross Lake and he asked
me if it would be permissible to have a period there for
religious education when he visited the settlement. I
told him how few Catholic children there were. He said
he didn't know but that there was a considerable number.
I told him I was on my way to visit the school and give
my answer upon my return.

I then proceeded to the Sagittawuk School,
this being my first visit since its opening. I found that
50% of the children attending were Catholic - 19 Catholic
and 19 Protestant. I asked Miss McDonald the teacher if
she would have any objection to allowing Father Trudeau
to hold an occasional period at any time of the day for
religious education so that if any Protestant children
were to be dismissed during that period. I informed her that
this was a purely temporary arrangement until I could get
the R.C. Day School built this summer on an adjacent site.
She said she had no objection and would be glad to coopera-
te. I so informed Father Trudeau on my return stipulating
that there should be no attempted proselytising and I infor-
med both Father Trudeau and Miss McDonald that under the
Act I should expel the 19 children from the Sagittawuk
School.

Upon receipt of a copy of a letter from Mr
Harvey to Father Trudeau, I proceeded at once to Cross Lake,
where I met Dr Best of the United Church. We talked the
whole matter over in the presence of Mr Harvey and the whole
affair was settled amicably, Father Trudeau withdrawing his
request and Dr Best agreeing that he would explain the
whole situation to Dr Dorey whom he would be seeing in
Toronto in a few days, so that Dr Dorey will now be in full
possession of the facts.

I am aware that I contravened the act but ever
since I came here I have been attempting by threats and
coaxing to compel children to attend school, also I have
been forced to take action under Sec 4(2) of Family Allowances
Act. To expel from school - 19 children who are capable
willing to attend because they approach the Almighty God by
a different manner and ritual from their fellows created &
paradox incomprehensible to their small minds and for that matter the minds of their parents. (With apologies to Clive of India) "Pecavi".

E.B. Goodman,
Superintendent, Indian Agency.
