INFORMATION FOR THE EMPLOYEE

8. Dependents. Taxpayers may claim as dependents only:

(1) A person under 18 years of age, or under 21 years of age and attending school, or over 18 years of age and incapable of self-support, who is wholly dependent upon the taxpayer for support, and in whom the taxpayer has, or immediately before such person attained the age of 21 years did have, in law or in fact, the custody and control.

(2) Sons and daughters (including illegitimate sons and daughters) or sons-in-law or daughters-in-law, brothers and sisters or brothers-in-law or sisters-in-law, and grandchildren under eighteen years of age, or under twenty-one and attending school, or over eighteen years of age and incapable of self-support.

(3) Parents, grandparents, parents-in-law, or grandparents-in-law, incapable of self-support.

(4) A daughter or sister under twenty-one years of age who is a nurse in a public or provincially licensed private hospital.

9. If Child under 16 and not Registerable for Family Allowances. A taxpayer may claim an exemption of $100 for each child under 16 years of age, a grandchild "that was or might have been registered under The Family Allowances Act, 1944, so that the allowance under the said Act was or might have been paid during any part of the last month of the taxation year." With a few exceptions, every child under 16 years of age may be registered and receive payments under the Family Allowances Act. Therefore, Form T.D.1 provides that only the $100 exemption may be claimed for any dependent shown in Item 5 as having been born after November 1931. There are some cases, however, of children under 16 years of age who are not registrable for family allowances. An employee supporting such a dependent child is entitled to claim the $300 exemption for tax purposes. The employer should be instructed to file a T.D.1 form in which an employee claims the $300 exemption for a child under 16 years of age.

may make deductions accordingly and he must immediately refer the T.D.1 form to the District Income Tax Office for confirmation, accompanied by a declaration signed by the employee outlining the facts which substantiate his claim that he has a child who is eligible for registration under The Family Allowances Act.

10. If Income of Spouse in Excess of $250. A taxpayer is not entitled to claim marital status if his (her) spouse's income is more than $750 during the calendar year. If the spouse will have an income of more than $250 but not more than $750, the exemption permitted for married status will be reduced by the amount by which the income of the spouse will exceed $250 (e.g., if the spouse's income will be say $600, then $350 should be entered in Item 6(B) (2) (i.e., $600 less $250). If the spouse's own income for the calendar year will be not more than $250, Item 6(B) (2) will be left blank and the full marital exemption of $750 entered in Item 6(B) (3).

11. "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" means a dwelling house, apartment or other similar place of residence containing at least two bedrooms in which the taxpayer and his family live as a general rule sleeps and has his meals prepared and served. (See Item 16).

12. Change in Status of Dependents. If during the year there is a change in the status or dependents of an employee, the employee must complete and file with his employer an amended Form T.D.1.

13. Missing Forms T.D.1. If an employee fails to file a completed Form T.D.1 not filed with the employer, deductions from all salaries or wages must be made as if the employee were a single person without dependents. Single persons without dependents need not file this form.

14. Filing of Income Tax Return. In addition to filing this form, the employee must file Income Tax Returns for T.I Employees or T.I Special or T.I General for the calendar year on or before 30th April of the following year.

INSTRUCTIONS TO THE EMPLOYER

15. If Form T.D.1 Not Filed By Employee. Any employee who fails to file a completed Form T.D.1 must be regarded for tax deduction purposes as a single person without dependents and deducting the amount shown in the current Table of Income Tax Deductions.

16. Employer to Scrutinize Claims by Single Persons for Married Status. The definition of a "Self-contained Domestic Establishment" contained in Item 11 indicates clearly that a taxpayer is not entitled to Married Status by merely supporting a dependent therein unless the dependent actually resides with the taxpayer. Therefore, employers are instructed to check the address shown under Item 4(B) (4) of each taxpayer's claim in Item 2 (which should show where he is actually living at the time of making the declaration) and even if the employee does not meet the same the employer must make deductions as if the taxpayer were a single person, with or without dependents as the case may be.

17. Employer's Responsibility Regarding Form T.D.1. The employer will have regard to the instructions contained in Item 16 above, will check the employee's computation of the total exemptions in Item 6 and will otherwise make certain that the form is fully completed. If the employee claims a dependent under Item 5 the name of any person whom the employee has already listed in Item 4 unless the claim for marital status cannot be paragraph (C) thereof. If the employee has reason to believe that any of the information on this form is incorrect or false, he will not act upon the declaration until the employee has made the appropriate corrections or corrections. In case of doubt the matter should be referred to the District Income Tax Office.

18. Action upon Receipt of Amended Form T.D.1 during Currency of Year. Employees are required to file an amended Form T.D.1 if any change occurs in their number of dependents. The employee should give immediate effect to a change from "Single" status to "Married" status and to an increase in the number of dependents. A change from "Married" status to "Single" status (e.g., where the employee becomes a widower) should not be made effective until the first pay period in the next calendar year because the employee will still be entitled to claim marital status for the balance of the calendar year in which the change took place. Similarly, a decrease in the number of dependents should not generally require a change in the deductions claimed until the next pay period. However, one important exception due to the provision that a taxpayer may not claim as a dependent any person who has an income in excess of $400 during the calendar year. If, for example, a son who was previously supported by an employee and was claimed as a dependent on Form T.D.1 takes employment from which he expects to earn $400 during the calendar year, immediate effect should be given to the amended form T.D.1 as otherwise the employee will be left with a substantial balance of tax to be deducted from future payments of Form T.I Employees or T.I Special or T.I General.

19. Further Information or Forms with respect to deduction of tax may be obtained from any District Income Tax Office.

20. Completed Forms T.D.1 must be Kept on File by the employer in order that they may be available at all times for payroll inspection by officers of the Taxation Division.

Dear Sir,

I wish to inform you that I am resigning my position as teacher in the Cross Lake United Church Day School; said resignation to become effective June 24, 1949.

I was anything but pleased at having to wait five months for my first check while I was employed in your school and would not care to risk a similar
experience a second time.

I have also found the school building to be very cold, small, and generally unsatisfactory and I have no desire to go through another winter in it. There is certainly nothing about it that would attract a teacher.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose the Quarterly Returns from the Cross Lake Day School for the Quarters ended Sept. 30th and Dec. 31st, 1927.

These reports reached this office about the end of January, while I was away visiting the outside reserves. When received, they were not in duplicate. I held them for some time waiting for the duplicate, but this has not arrived to date, so am sending them along, and keeping only a summary to check up with the office copy when it does arrive. I am visiting Cross Lake next week, all being well, and will then secure the duplicates.

Cross Lake, At 5 Winnipeg, Man., August 24/34.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Stanley, Ont.

Gentlemen,

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Kenneth Braden saying that my appointment to the Cross Lake Day School had been approved. I thank you for this appointment very much & will endeavour to do my very best.

Our mail service at Cross Lake is very limited and intermittent. On that account would you please make out my cheque payable to the Chatham, Ont., Canadian Bank of Commerce, to be deposited on my account there, in case of Miss Earle?

I would be glad if you could write me at Cross Lake by Sept 10 (so it will reach me on the last mail) and let me know if this arrangement will be convenient.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Mrs. Grace Savage.
Ottawa, August 27, 1934.

Madam:

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant, I beg to say that your monthly salary cheque will be drawn in your favour and forwarded to the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Chatham, Ont., for deposit to your credit.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Mrs. Grace Savage,
Teacher,
United Church Indian Day School,
Cross Lake, Man.
Ottawa, August 3, 1935.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the services of Mrs. Grace Savage have been discontinued as teacher of the Cross Lake United Church Indian Day School. The Church authorities have nominated Miss Constance Shoup to succeed her, and the Department is approving the appointment for the coming academic year. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $85 per teaching month. Mr. Inspector Hamilton is being informed of the appointment of Miss Shoup. She should begin duties when the school re-opens after the present holidays, on September third, next. I have to request that you will give her every possible assistance in her work at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

P. G. Lasenby, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

Ottawa, July 14, 1943.

Dear Doctor Dorey,

The Department has just received the resignation of Mr. John Loewen as teacher of the Cross Lake United Church Indian Day School. Dear Sir:

I am writing you regarding an important matter upon which I desire some information from the Department. In this, I refer to the Roman Catholic School here at Cross Lake. They apparently have a Day School, the children receiving two meals a day, and also clothing. Now we do not in the least object to this, but if theirs is an ordinary day school, then the Reserve School of equal standing should, it seems to me, receive equal treatment. If on the other hand the present arrangement for them is in lieu of a Residential School, then surely the same rule should apply that is enforced in all such schools; then only Catholic children would be eligible for attendance.

This seems to me to be a reasonable view of the Cross Lake situation, otherwise the Department would be aiding one church to proselyte the children of another which would certainly degrade education as well as religion. I would therefore respectfully urge upon the Department that Roman Catholics and Protestants keep to their own schools.

I trust that in bringing this matter before the Department it will not be considered an intrusion on my part.

Yours Sincerely,

Sir:

I have just had an interview with Miss M. I. Farris, who is in charge of the Indian Day School at Cross Lake, Norway House Agency. Miss Farris is a qualified teacher and has given two years service at this point.

During the first year and part of her second year, Miss Farris resided with the missionary and his wife, Mr. & Mrs. Gaudin. However, conditions in this relation became somewhat strained and Miss Farris was obliged to seek another boarding house. She rented a small shack which she fitted up and lived in until the close of the term. The shack belonged to a halfbreed and now that it has been put in shape, he intends to use it himself during the coming winter. Miss Farris has made enquiries in connection with other places, but is unable to secure accommodation. She requested permission to live above the classroom, but as this room is not finished and would be very cold, I do not think we should expect her to do this.

I am quite sure Miss Farris is prepared to remain at this point for some time and if at all possible, I would recommend that a small log house be erected close to the school - this could be supplied for about $150.00. Miss Farris is willing to supply the furnishings that will be necessary. If this work is to be carried out, authority should be granted at once in order that the necessary building material may be sent in not later than the 1st of September.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Sir,

I beg to report that on the 15th instant, I inspected the Cross Lake United Church Indian Day School.

There were 20 pupils in attendance at the time of my visit to this school, including both treaty and non-treaty children. Both teacher and pupils were doing good work, and the pupils' work shows some progress.

The school building was clean and tidy, considering the condition of the building itself.

This building is in very poor shape, and requires considerable repairing in a number of ways; siding is required at both top and bottom of the outside walls; corner boards are needed; a new door at the entrance &c;. There is no chimney to the building. The smoke pipe from the stove, which stands in the middle of the floor, goes through the ceiling and thence directly through the roof, and at some time or other, the roof surrounding this pipe has been on fire, and a portion perhaps three feet square has been burned through. This has since been covered with tin.

The stove is in bad shape, and anew one should be furnished. The present one is simply being held together with wire tied around it, without which the stove would fall apart. It is by no means safe.

I was given to understand, by the resident United Church missionary on this reserve that

Dear Mr. Beaton,

I have looked over the school building today and am attaching a list of what in my judgment would be necessary to put the building into a finished state. The building was never finished - not all siding on, no corner boards, window sashings and several other items. I've included all in the list enclosed. What it would cost for labor I cannot state. Mr. Perone is not here at the present.

In my judgment it would be a wise thing to put a porch on the front as a protection in winter. The door at present opens directly outside and any storms blowing from north, N.East or East strike it directly. These are our coldest quarters for storms. I have compiled a second sheet to cover the porch if required. I've figured all these quite carefully.

I may state the door at present is very badly shot up with light showing through its panels in several places.

As touching the stucco work. In my opinion that work is not necessary. The siding is in good state since the building is of a quite recent construction - just a year or so before I came here five years ago. It would not be wise to remove it to stucco nor would I think it be wise to go to expense of lathing and stuccoing over it.

I feel these other repairs made would place the school in as good condition as one could expect in this country.

The stove mentioned would indeed be a good thing but when the beans or soup etc., is prepared here they get on nicely with the drink. If, however, a suitable stove were placed in the school it would relieve Mrs. Shoup of considerable work which does not really belong to her work or responsibility.

All of this is respectfully submitted. I might add that to be properly painted would both add appearance and durability of the school.

Sincerely,

(sgd.) W. W. Shoup,

Norway House, Man:
26th December 1935.

Sir,

Under date of the 7th May 1935, I forwarded to the Department a copy of a requisition sent to me by Mrs Grace Savage, then teacher of the United Church Day School on the Cross Lake Reserve, for certain materials required for that school, including certain items of food for the mid-day meal.

Mrs Savage's requisition called for 200-cans of Condensed Milk, and possibly I made an error in copying the requisition, as the Department's letter No; 123-2-5 of the 21st May authorizing me to purchase the food stuff and other articles, authorized the purchase of but 1-case of milk, which is 48 cans.

I am now advised by the teacher, Miss Constance Shoup that they are out of milk, and will require three more cases to last out the balance of the fiscal year.

I have made enquiries both at Norway House and at Cross Lake as to what three cases of milk will cost. Three stores at Norway House quote from $10.50 to $11.05 per case, to which would have to be added freight to Cross Lake at $1.50 per 100 lbs. The Hudson's Bay Company right at Cross Lake quotes $11.04 per case, which is the cheapest of them all.

I therefore beg to requisition for authority to purchase 3 cases of Condensed Milk from the Hudson's Bay Company at Cross Lake, at a cost of $11.04 per case, for the above school.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Hazenby,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Re: School Equipment, Cross Lake

I am informed by the teacher at the Cross Lake Indian Day School that for two years in succession she has been asking for new desks through the Indian Agent, and the request has been ignored, while in the meantime the other denominational school at Cross Lake has received a complete new set of desks, and the Anglican school at Norway House has been similarly treated.

I do not know whether these are facts or not, but I think the Department should bear in mind that, contrary to our expectations, Miss Shop has made a great success of the school at Cross Lake and has surprised all of us who were responsible for her appointment. She has from ten to fifteen children using empty hard-teak biscuit boxes for both seats and desks. I wish you would take this matter up with Mr. Lazenby and that, if possible, the estimates for next year include an amount sufficient to provide some new equipment for the Cross Lake school.

The situation at Cross Lake is quite different from most of the other places in the North, as the people do not travel so far afield in the wintertime and an increasing number of them in recent years have been leaving their families at home when they go out to their trap-lines.

Thanking you for your attention to this matter,

I am

Yours sincerely,

In regard to several items on the requisition which were asked for last year and were not sent I wish to say:

The "Highroads to Rdg. Primers" are the primers authorized for Manitoba schools and lead up to the work in the Grade I Highroads to Rdg. text.

The "Highroads to Rdg." work books and "My Literature Books" follow the readers with daily exercises in reading seatwork. For two years I have supplied every child in the school with a work book paid for by myself because these are such a great help to the child in gaining comprehension in reading and in enlarging his knowledge of the English language. I feel they should be supplied by the Department and not at the teacher's own expense.

The newsprint is a cheap paper to be used on the hectograph for various children's seatwork exercises.

There have been no exercise books for writing practice in this school for the past two years. I have ordered
Primary Ruled Exercise Books for Grade VII and Freehand Copy Books for Grade III—Bailey Writing Books supplied by the Ideal Letter Cards are used almost every day in Beginners' seatwork and the free stock in the school have been here for six years that I know so they are badly depleted and outworn.

I have ordered transparent tape to repair several torn text books. Last year the doctor advised me to order two items for the health and cleanliness of the school. These were:

Elb (insect killer) for the children's hair and Kleenex to be used in school since there are few handkerchiefs and these are needed so continuously all year.

For the same matter of health I have asked for a metal Water Container for the school which will have a cover over the drinking water and a tap from which to draw the water, thus doing away with the unhealthy dipper and dirty pail now in use.

the reason I have stressed them here.

Dear Sirs:

The Department finds it necessary to return the enclosed account.

You will note that item No. 5 reads 2 brooms. Under the heading "quantity" you show the figure 1/3 and under the heading "price" you show $3.20.

Two brooms would be 1/6 of a dozen not 1/3 and if the price you are charging for these brooms is $3.20 a dozen the entry of $1.07 would be incorrect.

I regret to have to trouble you about a small matter like this but our accounts are very carefully audited and consequently they have to show distinctly the manner in which the charge is reached.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sirs:

Will you please refer to your letter of Oct. 9th, 1940 regarding our account of $58.33, covering goods supplied on June 14th, 1940 for your account, to Mr. H. Stevens, United Church Mission, Cross Lake, Man.

These goods have been out of our possession now for about seven months, and we think you will agree that the margin of profit in the grocery business, will not permit any wholesaler to carry accounts for this length of time without suffering a direct loss on the transaction.

We realise your difficult position in that up to the time of your last letter you had not received any word from Mr. Stevens. At the same time we think that, in all fairness, our account should be paid, since it is through no fault of ours that delay has been caused in your communication with the North country.

The goods were shipped in accordance with your instructions and doubtless reached their destination, otherwise we would have heard something about it, and under these circumstances we shall appreciate it if you will be good enough to send us a remittance for $58.33, in payment for this very much overdue invoice.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 28th September handed me last night by Mrs. Frank Meadows.

I received the requisition sent in by Mr. Harry Meadows for materials for repairing the school, but this was much too large for me to authorize without Departmental sanction, and it was too late to put the requisition through Ottawa, and get the materials to Cross Lake, even had they been eventually authorized. I have however, authority to have two suitable outdoor toilets built at your school, and I should be glad if you would see that this is done. The necessary number might probably be procured from the saw mill at the R.C.A. Mission, and the mails at the H.B. Co. The cost must be kept to the absolute minimum. Accounts for the materials for these toilets should be rendered to this office in three copies certified by yourself.

I note that you say the payment of treaty at the school left the building in a disgracefully dirty condition. The building was certainly not in a condition such as you describe the last time I saw it. However please have the inside cleaned and scrubbed, and paid for through the H.B. Co., in the usual way, concerning which Mr. Shalmers will advise you if you ask him. If I can get a man to take them, I will send you two sacks of cement, with which it should be possible to repair the cracks in the chimney. It should be possible to get someone on the reserve to the necessary labor re the toilets and the chimney, under your supervision, and I should be glad if you would do this.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

I arrived at Cross Lake on Sept. 24 to take over the teaching duties at the United Church Indian Day School. I will commence teaching on Oct. 1 as directed.

I was very disappointed in the school. Much cleaning and repairing are necessary before the school will be ready for use. I have seen the Catholic Mission school and I think there is too great a difference in the appearance of the two buildings for both being supported by the government. From my experience I have noticed that school children take a pride in attending a school which is as good or better than their neighbors and the teacher can expect good results only when the conditions under which he works are favorable.

The payment of Treaty money in the school during August left the building in a disgracefully dirty condition.

I believe Mr. Meadows has informed you of the condition of the school and that you had him forward a requisition for the required repair material but to date none has arrived. He has told me that you are interested in improving the condition of the building so I trust that you will see to it that I am given the opportunity to make my school presentable and conducive to good work on the part of the children. I regret that my first letter to you is one of complaint but if you have seen the school you will know that complaint is justified. Looking forward to a pleasant association with you, I am,

Yours truly,

(signed) John E. Leowen.

Dear Sir:

This is to report that the Indian Boys School operated by this mission was completely destroyed by fire on Wednesday March 24th. The entire contents were also destroyed. The fire originated in a defective chimney.

I took up the matter of the defective chimney and the condition of the entire school with the Indian Agent as long ago as last August when he paid treaty in the building but nothing was done about it. The cement chimney was cracked so badly that creosote had run out of the cracks and seeped through the ceiling and gone all over the teacher's desk and floor. The Agent complained of this but did not go upstairs to inspect the chimney. I pointed out to him that the whole building was in very poor condition and that if things were left until the teacher arrived it would be too late to have anything done. He agreed that this was true and asked me to go over the building and note what was needed and forward a requisition to him. This was done and I personally gave him the requisition on August 21, 1942. I am enclosing the duplicate of this requisition; you will note that the need for a new chimney is pointed out as the old one was cracked and falling apart.

As no repair material arrived and no letter was received from the Agent by the time the teacher arrived he wrote the Agent on Sept. 28, 1942, pointing out the very bad condition of the building and the need for repairs. A copy of his letter is enclosed. A copy of the Indian Agent's reply is also enclosed. You will note that he had done nothing whatever about the requisition he had had me make out, because he considered it large. He had not even forwarded it to Ottawa for consideration. I should like to point out that it would have been possible to get the material in to Cross Lake as late as six weeks after the requisition was filed with him. Even if it was not the proper time for requisition to go forward to Ottawa it strikes me that a defective chimney is a serious enough matter to be dealt with at any time, it has certainly proved so. The cement which he mentioned that he might send never did arrive and the chimney was never repaired.
My predecessor in this mission, Mr. F.W. Stevens complained of the school's condition and the condition of the chimney to the Agent at the time of the treaty payment in 1941 so that certainly did not lack knowledge of it.

I am making this report and forwarding the enclosures in order that you might have full knowledge of the situation it is apparent to me as I believe it will be to you that the Indian Agent's neglect has cost the Department a building which, while it was not good, would with a little repair have served as a school for many years to come.

The teacher Mrs. Loewen is at present carrying on in a building belonging to this mission.

Yours truly,

H.Meadows

Ottawa, April 14, 1943.

Mr. P. G. Lasenby, Indian Agent, Norway House, Manitoba.

You notified the Department, in a telegram dated March 27, that the United Church Indian Day School at Cross Lake had been, with its contents, totally destroyed by fire.

We are now in receipt of a letter dated March 26, 1943, signed by Harry Meadows, United Church Missionary at Cross Lake, which reads in part as follows:

"I took up the matter of the defective chimney and the condition of the entire school with the Indian agent as long ago as last August, when he paid treaty in the building, but nothing was done about it. The cement chimney was cracked so badly that creosote had run out of the cracks and soaked through the ceiling and gone all over the teacher's desk and floor. The agent complained of this but did not go up stairs to inspect the chimney. I pointed out to him that the whole building was in very poor condition and that if things were left until the teacher arrived it would be too late to have anything done. He agreed that this was true and asked me to go over the building and note what was needed and forward a requisition to him. This was done and I personally gave him the requisition on August 21, 1942. I am enclosing the duplicate of this requisition. You will note that the need for a new chimney is pointed out as the old one was cracked and falling apart.

"As no repair material arrived and no letter was received from the agent by the time the teacher arrived, he wrote the agent on September 25, 1942, pointing out the very bad condition of the building and the need for repairs. A copy of his letter is enclosed. A copy of the Indian agent's reply is also enclosed. You will note that he had done nothing whatever about the requisition he had me make out, because he considered it large. He had not even forwarded it to Ottawa for consideration. I should like

COPY SENT TO INSPECTOR HAMILTON
to point out that it would have been possible to get the material in to Cross Lake as late as 6 weeks after the requisition was filed with him. Even if it was not the proper time for a requisition to go forward to Ottawa, it strikes me that a defective chimney is a serious enough matter to be dealt with at any time. It has certainly proved so."

We should like to receive from you immediately any comments you may care to make in respect to Mr. Meadows' statement. We are anxious to know if the requisition to which he refers was sent forward to the Department. There is nothing on file here to indicate that it reached this Branch. If it was not submitted, we should like an explanation as to why you did not consider it necessary to send forward this requisition for supplies and why you did not deem it necessary to have the chimney, which appeared to be in a dilapidated condition at the time of your visit, repaired at once.

A requisition for certain supplies necessary at the Cross Lake United Church School, dated March 5, 1943, reached the Department on April 6. It was exceedingly difficult for the officials here, immediately following the receipt of this requisition, to decide whether these supplies had been requested for the school now destroyed by fire or for the temporary mission building now in use. In order that there might be no delay, Inspector Hamilton was authorized, on April 7, to purchase the materials and to have them shipped immediately following the opening of navigation on Lake Winnipeg.

To neglect to bring to the attention of the Department certain fire hazards that may exist at Indian day schools or other government-owned buildings is a very serious matter at any time. Your alleged failure in this case has resulted in the destruction of the Cross Lake School, at a time when it is exceedingly difficult to secure the funds necessary for the maintenance and operation of our schools and when it is impossible to secure either the funds or the materials required for replacement. You will be expected to submit, at the earliest possible date, a full and complete explanation in respect to this matter. You should report particularly on your alleged
failure to forward the requisition and your apparent failure to take immediate steps to have the chimney repaired. I beg to confirm my radiogram of the 26th March addressed to the Department, and reading as follows:

RECEIVED RADIOGRAM FROM TEACHER UNITED CHURCH DAY SCHOOL AT CROSS LAKE ADVISING THAT SCHOOL BUILDING AND CONTENTS DESTROYED BY FIRE ON TUESDAY MORNING STOP CARRYING ON AS BEST HE CAN FOR PRESENT IN BUILDING LOANED BY CHURCH STOP WILL WRITE WHEN RECEIVE FULLER REPORT.

Since dispatching the above radiogram, the teacher himself has visited the office, and advised me that on the 24th March, the last stick of wood he put in the stove was put in at about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and the fire occurred at about 9.30 p.m. On finding that the school soon after the fire broke out, he went in and looked in the stove, but there was only a stub a double handful of glowing coals in the back of the stove. The building took fire in the roof near the chimney, which apparently has been cracked for some time. The chimney was built of concrete. There was no way of saving either the building or the contents.

The teacher secured the loan of a small building belonging to the United Church, in which to carry on the school, and purchased a quantity of rough lumber from the R.O. Residential School with which to make up some tables and seats. The Residential School also supplied him with a few books such as readers and arithmetic, and also sent him some scribblers, readers and pencils which I obtained from the Residential School at Norway House. He lacks a blackboard however, but succeeded to get a very small one about two feet by three feet, from the Hudson's Bay Company at Cross Lake, and although he now has he hopes to be able to carry on fairly well for the balance of the school term. The teacher stated that he did not keep all his school materials in the school building, but just what he required for immediate use, and so a small quantity was thus available from the school's own stores.

With the exception of the desks, which were fastened to the floor, I believe, the total loss is not by any means great. The building was a very old one, of log construction. There was no teacher's desk, a rickety little table being used in place of one. There was a small cupboard, home made, of rough boards, and the blackboard, which was also much the worse for wear. The school bell, which hung in the porch over the door was chopped off and saved from the fire by the teacher.

The teacher states that he cannot understand how

I beg to acknowledge receipt of The Director's letter No; 123-2-5 of the 14th instant, regarding the burning down of the Cross Lake U.C. Indian Day School, and quoting therein certain extracts from a letter addressed to the Department by Mr Harry Meadows, the United Church Missionary at Cross Lake, concerning the same subject.

In reply, I beg to say that on August 5th last, the day I completed treaty payment at Cross Lake, I looked over the building, and, contrary to the statement made by Mr Meadows in his letter, I went upstairs to see the chimney while the Agency Clerk was busy balancing collections made, with the various traders' accounts. I noted that the cement chimney was cracked, and that some creosote had leaked through the ceiling into the school room below. In his letter, Mr Meadows states that "...creosote had run out of the cracks and soaked through the ceiling and gone all over the teacher's desk and floor." This statement would seem calculated to give the impression that a teacher's desk had been destroyed in the fire, and that a very large amount of creosote had leaked into the schoolroom. The fact is, that the teacher had no desk, but used a small homemade table, and as for the creosote, there was a small spot on this table, and a spot on the floor beside it probably about a foot square. This particular point has no special value, excepting that it indicates exaggeration, and Mr Meadows' desire to put as bad a complexion as possible on matters.

In talking over with Mr Meadows the matter of doing some repair work at the school, I asked him to figure out what repairs he thought were necessary, and suggested to him that the inside of the school could do with some painting, and requested him to make out a list of what might be required, with a minimum of expense. My own opinion was that the building being in very poor condition, it was not worth spending very much money on, and I expected to receive from Mr Meadows a small list of things that I could have purchased direct from

- Winnipeg -
Winnipeg, without having to send a requisition through Ottawa, and encounter that much delay. After I received the requisition, and saw how large it was, I took the first opportunity of asking the Captain of the Selkirk Navigation Co's tug how many more trips he was going to make to Whiskeyjack, and he advised me that he was going that same week, and the week following, if I remember correctly. This would preclude the possibility of shipping the materials on the requisition to Whiskeyjack on the tug, as there would not be time to forward the requisition to Ottawa get the materials purchased and shipped in time. I therefore decided to try to send some cement to Cross Lake with which to repair the chimney, if I could find anyone going there by canoe, and withhold the requisition until this spring and send it in with all the other school requisitions, then have the whole job of repairing the school done during this summer holidays.

Mr Meadows forwarded with his letter to Ottawa, a copy of the teacher's letter to me of September 28th, and a copy of my reply thereto. From the copy of my reply, it will be noted in the last paragraph that I mentioned that I was intending to send the cement for repairing the chimney if an opportunity presented. I am unable to say now, whether or not the cement was sent, as no record of it would be kept, the cement being some that was left over from some other jobs at the agency. However, the teacher, Mr John Loewen, was at Norway House during the Christmas holidays, about December 29th or 30th, and came to see me at the office. In talking about the school, he mentioned that they had 'got the chimney patched up, and it was not too bad now'. He also remarked that sometimes smoke leaked through the stove pipe joints, but not as bad as before.

In his letter, Mr Meadows states that "...it would have been possible to get the material in to Cross Lake as late as 6 weeks after the requisition was filled with him." I suppose that by this, he means that freeze-up did not occur until that time, but that does not mean that transportation by water to Cross Lake was available, or possible, as late as that, as it certainly was not.

If the chimney was still 'defective', as Mr Meadows states, after it had been patched up as I was advised by the teacher, then one would think that some extra care might have been taken in the putting on of fires, and seeing that no fire was left in the stove when school closed in the afternoons. As it was, there was still fire in the stove at 9.30 p.m., six and a half hours after the last previous time wood had been put in, as I mentioned in my letter to the Department of April 14th, so that there was evidently a very large fire put in at 3 p.m. and there must have been still a large fire in at 4 p.m. when...
scholars and teacher left the building for the night. In contrast to this, I may say that at the Norway House Public School, where the chimney is not defective, the teacher sees that all the fire is raked out of the stove before leaving the building at 4 p.m.

With reference to the requisition recently forwarded to the Department for the Cross Lake U.C. School, I beg to say that the materials asked for on Page 3, for "Repairs for the School" will not now be required, but I expect the materials on Pages 1 and 2 will be required. With reference to the materials on Page 3, I beg to say that on April 15th I received a letter from Mr Inspector Hamilton advising that he had been instructed to purchase some supplies for the Cross Lake U.C. School, among which was the item, 1 - Chimney, (5t brick), and Mr Hamilton asked me to advise him what was required for this item. I replied to Mr Hamilton's letter on the same day, advising him that the bricks for the chimney would not now be required, as the school building had been destroyed by fire on March 24th. From this it is probable that Mr Hamilton would conclude that the rest of the materials would also not be required. However, I will wire Mr Hamilton as soon as it is possible to reach the radio station, and advise him. I may say that The Director's letter, to which this is a reply, arrived on the last mail plane before break-up, and the ice has not been safe to travel on since that time. It will possibly be three or four more weeks before this letter leaves Norway House, which will account for the delay in receiving it at Ottawa.

F.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, June 10, 1943.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Re: Destruction United Church Indian Day School, Cross Lake, Manitoba.

I am sending forward herewith correspondence relating to the destruction of the above-noted building. The subject matter of this correspondence, you will note, is self-explanatory.

Mr. Lazenby, in his letter dated April 26, submits a lengthy explanation of his failure to take the action necessary to repair the chimney at the school. This explanation, however, in my judgment, is faulty in a number of particulars. For example, it would appear that it was his intention to send forward cement for the repair of the chimney, but in his letter you will note he states:

"I am unable to say now whether or not the cement was sent, as no record of it would be kept, the cement being some that was left over from some other jobs at the agency."

In view of the acute fire hazard that existed at this school at the time of the agent's visit, it is exceedingly difficult to understand why he did not assume personal responsibility for sending on the supplies and materials necessary for this work.

The officials of this Branch have had a feeling for a couple of years that Mr. Lazenby has neither the health nor the physical stamina necessary to administer the affairs of the Norway House Agency. The care of government property at Indian day and residential schools, teachers' residences and agency buildings, generally, is the responsibility of the agent. It should not be...
necessary for a school teacher to remind him from time to time that a fire hazard exists at any particular building.

In view of all the circumstances, I am disposed to think that consideration should be given to the desirability of transferring Mr. Lasenby to another agency or to a position where the duties and responsibilities would be less exacting.

Encl.

Acting Director.

I have just received word from the Mission Board that my plan for converting our large warehouse here into a school have been approved and so have had work commenced on it. I understand that your department is having the school furniture supplied, however as no requisition for furniture has been sent in, I am forwarding one herewith. Yours truly,

Dear Doctor Dorsey:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 20th instant, in which you ask for payment of $300.00 for certain repairs and alterations that have been made to the temporary school building at Cross Lake.

I am particularly anxious that a cheque for this amount should reach Mr. Meadows prior to the close of navigation. It is my understanding that the last boat this year may leave Winnipeg on or about October 4.

I have this morning discussed this matter very fully with Mr. McCutcheon, Chief Treasury Officer. He informs me that it will not be possible to make a payment of this kind until we have a statement from Mr. Meadows, signed by him and the Indian agent, giving in detail the amount of money spent on the purchase of material, hours of labour, etc. If we had this statement, no difficulty would be experienced in sending forward the cheque.

I have been wondering if it would be possible for you to send forward a cheque to Mr. Meadows, from church funds, on the understanding that he be asked to secure this statement of the work accomplished and forward it to us. We could then reimburse you for the amount paid by you. I must state, however, that immediately following the close of navigation there will be only two mails in to Norway House during the winter season and probably none between the close of navigation and Christmas. With these facts in your possession, you can turn the matter over in

Sup't. Welfare and Training Service,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sirs,

Your letter of 29th ult. has just reached me. In order that you might know that the matter is receiving attention and that you may have some of the information desired; I have today wired a brief reply.

The question of the type of school required here is not easily decided. If the Department has in mind the conventional school for instruction in the conventional school program there is no difficulty. However, some Department officials have given me the impression that the Department intends extending its educational program along other lines. If this is the case future needs should be kept in mind when deciding the type of school to be erected.

I believe a school could be of great use here in the matter of adult education. There is real need for instruction in the canning and preserving of meat and vegetables. Cross Lake is a wonderful place for gardening and much can be done along these lines as the people are ready for it. I have accomplished some things in this direction through the mission. A school with an adequate basement and equipped with a cooking range would be ideal. A school of the type of Berens River (Manitoba) United Church Indian Day school would serve the purpose. The basement could also be used as a dining hall where the noon lunches could be served. Such a school could become a real community centre and do much more than instruct in the "three 'R's'". Cross Lake people not only need such a community centre but have advanced to the point where they realize their need.

A teacher's residence would be almost a necessary part of such a school plant, but with the materials available in this country it could be erected at no great expense. At the price at which we can get lumber there is no need for running into great expense in building.
On March 4th I wrote stating that in my opinion it would be a mistake to build the school on the site of the former one and suggesting that I make a survey to ascertain the best location of a school. Actually I have almost completed this survey and have only to transfer the information to maps make the situation clear to the Department. My survey clearly shows me that one school, no matter what its type may be, cannot adequately serve the needs of this reserve. If you can probably surmise this reserve has a school-age population of approximately 200. The settlement stretches for about five miles along the shores of the river and lake. This means that the children to be served by a day school, and they are in the majority, will have very long walks in winter and long boat trips in summer if there is only one Day School. The result is that they will not (and do not) attend.

If the Department has a conventional one-room school in mind it would appear to me to be the best plan to split the appropriation and build two such schools. I know that I could build two such schools for $2,500 certainly not more than $3,000. If this is done I would suggest that one school be built on the old site and the other for the children living in the central part of the reserve, and this would also satisfy the Indians who seem to think that the school should always be where it always was.

The second school should be built in the 'Sa-ki-to-wah' community which is the northernly part of the reserve and which has a very large child population. There is a good site in this community and I believe I could get the Indians to agree to having a school built there quite readily.

The children from the southerly end of the reserve could be cared for without the erection of a third school if day-classes could be arranged for at St. Joseph's Residential School.

Now as to materials available locally, St. Joseph's School operates a sawmill and supplies the community with lumber at very reasonable rates, they are:

| Lumber Type       | Price per M. |
|-------------------|--------------|
| Rough lumber      | $30.00       |
| Dressed lumber    | $40.00       |

I called on the Principal of St. Joseph's today to see if his mill would be capable of supplying lumber in the quantity required for a building such as a school house. He stated that it could easily be done aside from flooring. The mill turns out flooring but it is spruce which is not suitable. However, he declared if he still had the lumber necessary to operate the mill full time this summer, he could not state definitely that he would able to supply the lumber. In any case it would require a year to dry and would not be fit for use this summer.

This means that if the school is to be built this summer, material (aside from logs for beams and a small quantity of seasoned lumber available here), most-of-the-meteskah will have to be procured outside and the cost greatly increased.

With regard to labor, you do not state whether the Department intends sending a carpenter or carpenters in to do the job. From your letter I get the impression that you wish to know whether or not this building could be erected with local labor under my supervision as the job was done last summer. This could be done, but it would be better to get at least one qualified carpenter on the job. I have had a good deal of experience but do not consider myself a professional builder at all. I can get labor and one or two fairly good Indian carpenters with whom I could do the job if necessary. I should
Mr. R. A. Hoey,

I know your wishes before the middle of April as these men are planning to leave the Reserve for work outside as soon as summer comes. However if I am able to offer them work here at home they will be glad to stay.

I myself am planning to leave here this summer, if however you wish me to stay to look after this work I shall be pleased to co-operate with you. My successor will not be here during July when the work should be under way and it will of course take him some time to orient himself after his arrival, even then he may not be able to undertake such a job.

We should have this whole matter settled by the middle of April as our mail service will then be interrupted by break-up, after that communication would have to be by telegram.

I realize that your time must be fully occupied with matters of greater importance than the subject of this letter, and that you must have little time for such lengthy reports as this, but I have wanted to give you a complete picture of the situation here so that the Department will be in a better position to determine what will best meet its educational needs. I will do my utmost to see that the appropriation is not only spent for a school but invested in such a way as to bring the greatest dividends in an educated and improved community, I am.

Yours sincerely,

H. H. Meadows

Reverend Sir:

I desire to refer to your letters of March 4 and March 10, in connection with the proposed erection of an Indian day school on the Cross Lake Reserve. As requested in your letter of the 4th instant, I enclose blueprint of the reserve on which you can indicate the population areas and possible sites for a school. I have noted your suggestion that instead of one school two be erected. It has occurred to me that possibly the best solution would be to build one new school at a convenient site and, for a further period of time, continue to use the present school. It scarcely seems necessary to add that any site suggested should be agreeable to the Cross Lake Band.

I agree that a building similar to the one at Berens River should serve the purpose at Cross Lake. Such a building would provide the facilities which you mention are needed. I am also inclined to feel that the lumber should be bought this year and it could then have a year to dry and the building could be erected in the summer of 1945. Please speak to the Principal of the St. Joseph's School again with a view to ascertaining definitely if he can supply the amount of lumber that would be required.

I am not certain from your letter if you are only leaving Cross Lake for a holiday or

REPORT ON NORWAY HOUSE INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF APRIL, 1944

Health:

The health of the Indians of the Norway House band has been generally good throughout the month.

The Field Matron at Cross Lake Reserve reports that common colds have been very prevalent amongst the Indians there, but reports also that the health of the children who attend the Day School regularly was noticeably better than that of the other reserve children, owing to getting one good meal a day at the school and daily doses of Cod Liver Oil.

No report has been received during the month regarding the health of the Indians of the other reserves.

I am leaving Norway House on the treaty trip, on July 17th, and will not be at Cross Lake until August 1st, and there is not time for me to do anything before that time. In your letter to Mr Meadows, of March 28th last you state that you..."agree that a building similar to the one

Map of Cross Lake Indian Reserve:
The shaded areas indicate the Cross Lake Indian Reserve. If this area is reduced in size, the features of the terrain become less distinguishable, namely Cross Lake and its many water courses, the islands, and the marshes.

It is evident from the map that though Cross Lake Reserve is large all settlement is concentrated along the banks of a number of Cross Lake streams. The majority of the Indians are considered semi-nomadic and are scattered in little groups making settlement almost impossible.

On the map the areas of settlement are divided into groups A-D, C-D, E-F, G-H. These areas of settlement are divided by the topography of the terrains, lakes, channels, or swamps between them.

The population of A to B has a population of children under 12 years of age of 50. All children attend school at the present time. However, the school is overcrowded and the school building is in poor condition.

The population of C to D has a population of children under 12 years of age of 40. The school was destroyed by fire last fall.

The population of E to F has a population of children under 12 years of age of 30. The school is overcrowded and the school building is in poor condition.

The population of G to H has a population of children under 12 years of age of 20. The school is overcrowded and the school building is in poor condition.

If the new school is built at the point indicated it will serve the children living in the area of E-F and if the present school is continued to be used it will serve the children living in the area of G-H.

As soon as possible I should recommend that a school be built in the C-D section and that the school be constructed so that the children do not have to cross a water course to get to school. When the school is completed it should serve all the children in the section E-F. I would recommend that this school be built first.

INSPECTOR'S REPORT ON NORWAY HOUSE INDIAN AGENCY

The Indians complained about the education the children obtain from the boarding schools. They feel it does not go far enough and their children cannot qualify for teachers, office help or to in any way compete with the white people. They feel the young people cannot always remain on the reserve, and looking to the future the Government should make it possible for the children to get advanced education or vocational training to fit them for different occupations. They are short of public school accommodation. Certainly another school is needed and I would refer to Mr. Lazonby's letter concerning the location dated November 28th, 1944, in reply to Departmental letter dated June 23rd, 1944, file 123-2-5.

While in Cross Lake on the 13th inst I spent the best part of a day choosing a suitable site which would accommodate the most children. I succeeded in locating a site which is both pleasing and suitable and which would serve about half the children of this community. It is known as the Sagittawuk settlement.

Father Trudeau pointed out to me that this site would serve an equal or possibly greater number of R.C. children, 17 of whom are at present with his consent attending the U.C. Day School now in operation. He made the suggestion that instead of building a 1 room school on the selected site that a 2 room school be built, 1 room for the U.C. and the other room for the R.C. children. This would require the construction of 2 teacherages. He informed me that it is the intention of his church to employ a lay teacher in their school and not a sister of any order. This proposition has its merits and is worthy of consideration. If this should be approved, it would mean an alteration in my building plans.

Two more day schools, 1 U.C. and 1 R.C. will eventually have to be built on the other side of the lake to accommodate the balance of the children and a similar establishment would take care of the situation there when such buildings are authorized by the Branch. Please let me know if the Branch is prepared to consider and authorize the a/m plan. As far as I can see I will be unable to do any building at Cross Lake until August after the treaty payments have been completed.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

While in Cross Lake paying treaty I engaged the services of Mr Earl Adams of the Pas as carpenter to build the U.C. Day School and Teacherage. He is at present working for the Manitoba Government erecting a house for their Game Guardian. He is being paid at the rate of $1.25 per hour and board. I told him that we would pay him at the same rate. This is the same rate which is also being paid to Hudson's Bay Co carpenters in this area and I do not see how we can do otherwise than pay the same rate if we expect to get a carpenter. The lumber and shingles I will supply locally.

Mr Adams will be ready to go to work in about 2 weeks time. Work has already started on this project under the supervision of Mr Adams for which he is making no charge such as clearing the ground, hauling of gravel and rocks, and excavating for the basements.

I am borrowing money from the Medical Account to pay current expenses. I therefore request an Accountable Advance of $4000.00 to pay for labor. As stated before Mr Adams will be ready to go to work in about 2 weeks time and to date the following supplies have not arrived:

1. 300 bags cement
2. Materials for bldg 2 chimneys 30' & 26' high respectively and the 1 for the school being double flue.
3. 16 pieces 2" round iron as listed in my requisition of Mar 29 1947
4. 24 rolls roofing paper
5. 22 rolls tarpaper & nails as per requisition referred to above

These supplies are most urgently needed, otherwise I will be unable to proceed with the project. In any event I very much doubt if these buildings can be erected within the amount provided of $8000.00. I assure you that I will endeavour to keep expenses within this limit. It would be appreciated if you would inform me as to whether it is O.K. with regard to the hiring of Mr Adams. Other labor will range from 30 to 80 cents per hour according to the nature of the work.

I trust that every effort will be made to forward the necessary supplies listed above. I might mention at this time also that the cement for the Jack River C of Z Teacherage has not arrived. The basement has been excavated and we are unable to proceed further.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Cross Lake U.C. Indian Day School

Mr. H. B. Goodman, Indian Agent at Norway House, Manitoba, has undertaken the construction of the much needed one-room day school and teacherage at Cross Lake, Man., our Departmental Purchasing Agent has procured the necessary materials and they are now being shipped north to Mr. Goodman. The rough lumber and shingles are being supplied locally from our own mill.

Mr. Goodman has now the possibility of engaging the services of Mr. Earl Adams of The Pas as foreman to supervise the construction of this building. Mr. Adams is at present working for the Manitoba Government, erecting a house for their game guardian. He is being paid at the rate of $1.25 per hour and board ($40.00 per month).

The above rate is the same as that being paid to Hudson's Bay Company carpenters in this area. Mr. Adams has already provided some supervision for the Indians working on this project and because of his efforts the ground is cleared, gravel and rocks have been hauled and the basement is partially excavated. Could we please have your approval for the hiring of Mr. Adams for this construction job.

All the material needed is there with the exception of 2500 bricks, 4 bags of lime and some tarpaper. Cross Lake U.C. Day School
Sept. 9th., 1947

Dear Ronnie,

As you know, our school is very small. It has only got 33 seats in it. That is not enough for us to have a seat for every child that comes to our school. We are sorry that that is the way things are and we hope that the government will soon have the new school finished so that there will be enough room for every child that wants to come to school. But right now things are so bad that we are not going to be able to give your children very good schooling. So this is what we are going to have to do.

Starting tomorrow, only children of parents that go to our church will be able to come to our day school. There are 33 of these children who have their names on our school list. That is just the number we have seats for and that is all we can take. So will you please not let your child come tomorrow? I know it will be hard for you to have to send them all the way to the Catholic day school; but I hope you will see why we are doing this. We must look after our own children first. That is the only reason. I will be glad to see you about this if you want to come to see me about it.

Yours truly,

Colonel Neary visited Cross Lake U.C. Indian Day School 13 Sept '47.

The temporarily used classroom is off the reserve near the Rev. Ian Harvey's house as explained in his attached letter to an Indian there is room for only 33 pupils. Thirteen R.C. pupils have to be dealt with.

At my suggestion the Agent has ordered some work to be done on the lean-to to make it less airy in winter.

The school is otherwise quite a respectable installation. Dimensions 22' x 26'.

Lacking a specially dispatched teacher as yet. Mrs. Jean Harvey, B.A., a qualified, experienced teacher was sworn in as mistress pro tem.

Bulletins checked. Complete course of studies has been obtained. Register correct. Supply situation good. One shipment of books must be further investigated.

The bridge in photo #2 permits traffic over the slough to the settlement beyond (Cox #500) the creek at Sagitowak where U.C. school is now under construction.

Rev. Father Trudeau who accompanied the inspection party claims there is a need for similar facilities for Roman Catholics at Sagitowak. The Agent agrees. Investigation shows that the terrain and unpredictable squalls on the water preclude the children of this settlement from attending a day school anywhere else on the reserve.

Needed in the Cross Lake Area:
Day schools for each church at Sagitowak for each also across the river from Residential School. In the Catholic Church a third classroom at a point to be agreed upon.

The attached list is of materials that are necessary to complete the U.C. Indian Day School and Teacherage at Cross Lake. The Beaverboard required on this list is necessary for the teacherage and about 40% of the Gyproc supplies was so badly damaged on arrival that it is unusable. It is also heavy and too brittle to withstand repeated handling, which materials have to undergo to be imported into this country and I advise against any further use of Gyproc.

Mr E Adams the foreman is going to his home in The Pas over the Freeze-up period but will return to Cross Lake to finish these 2 buildings on approximately November 15th, according to the season.

I visited and inspected these buildings last week and spent 2 days with Mr Adams. The outside work on both buildings is completed, and he has made a very fine job of them. Mr Adams suggests that he be allowed to purchase these materials in the Pas and bring them back with him when he returns. I think that this would be a good arrangement. I informed Mr Adams that I would have to obtain your permission for him to do so. Will please advise me by wire if this is permissible. They should be addressed United Church Indian Day School, c/o Mr E Adams, Cross Lake, via Wabowden. Mr Adams will arrange to have this material taken in from Wabowden to Cross Lake by horses.

Mr. Moffat inspected the above school on January 15th and his report was on the whole quite satisfactory. In part he wrote as follows:

"Mr. and Mrs. Harvey share the teaching load and are doing a very fine job indeed. Both go much beyond what is ordinarily expected of a teacher by attempting to give what is learned in school some practical application in the community. The community has learned to work together as shown by the fact that the school was built by the people of the district as a community project. (provincial school). The leadership given by the Harvey's is of the very best type since it shows the people how to help themselves. They are very properly trying to develop this in the school and the community at the same time. There is considerable evidence that their work is succeeding".

21 July 1948.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't Mines & Resources, Ottawa

Enclosed herewith in triplicate is a requisition for Eavestroughing for the Sagittawuk U.C. Indian Day School and Teachers Residence which was built last year at Cross Lake.

I was to Cross Lake this past Sunday and went over this building with Mr Frank Hughes, A/Superintendent and Mr Earl Adams, the carpenter who built same and Eavestrough is urgently needed for this building or the foundation will be ruined. This past week we have had several heavy rains and the earth around this building has caved in completely.

When Mr Adams went to Cross Lake late in May to build the Sagittawuk R.C. Combined School & Teacherage he examined the a/m school and on his own had a second coat of paint put on the exterior of this building, also the Teacherage. The cost of same was $75.00. The interior of both School & Teacherage requires a second coat of paint at an estimated cost of approximately $75.00. This second coat of paint was not applied at time building was complete due to arrival of a teacher to take up residence.

I request an Accountable Advance of $200.00 to cover painting already done plus painting of interior and installation of Eavestrough. May this request receive favourable consideration.

Q.P. Jackson,
Agency Clerk

Sir,

With reference to the letter addressed to you by Father Comeau, and forwarded to me for a report thereon, relative to the teacher of Ebb and Flow day School:

I have the honour to report as follows,-

I have visited the school on this reserve, three times, and on each occasion I found the school in about the same condition, little or no advancement shown, this was explained by the teacher to the wandering habits of the parents, and their lack of interest in the school.

On the 24th ultimo I had a visit from the Chief of the reserve, and two of his headmen, they stated that the teacher was not attending to his duties, that the school was often closed, that the children came frequently to the school, in the morning, and were given their biscuits and sent home, at other times he did not put in an appearance at all, their opinion was that the teacher was lazy, they also stated that the teacher was trading and neglected the school on that account. Mr. Dumas has performed his outside services to my satisfaction. I think a change of teachers would be advisable, and would recommend that the request of the Rev. Father be complied with.

I am, Sir, Your obedient servant,

(Sgd) S.R. Marlatt.

In reply to your letter of the 10th January 1916, No. II6770/1, I beg to say that when I was out at the Ebb and Flow Reserve, on the 26th January, I could get very little information about this matter. Miss Adams has left the Reserve and Beauchamp was also away, and the Chief and the other Indians all take the side of Beauchamp and say that Miss Adams is to blame for all the trouble, as far as I can find out, it is a question of taking Miss Adams word against Beauchamp, and the rest of the Band, which I consider would be poor evidence to commit Beauchamp on.

The only way I see to get evidence is to engage someone to go up there as the Indians will not give me any information against Beauchamp. Miss Adams is sick at the present time, and wants to have her sister take her place until she recovers from her illness, but what I can find out about this Band, that it is no place for any girl to be, but what they require is to have a teacher there who has will power enough to resist the demands made by the Indians. I find at several Reserves, that the teachers have been in the habit of lending these supplies to the Indians, at times and there is no doubt in my mind, that Miss Adams allowed Beauchamp to take these supplies and he did not return them when asked to do so.

EBB & FLOW SCHOOL.

A day school is maintained on the Reserve under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. The building is a log one, and has a shingled roof. At the time I visited the school it was locked up for the period of the summer vacation, and the teacher had gone on holiday. Sir.—
I beg to report that Miss Laura J. Davis, teacher of the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School is leaving the last of this month. This girl is not very satisfactory, and I do not get very good reports about her up on the Reserve.

I would recommend that Mrs. John Campbell, (nee Laura Shannon) be appointed teacher in the place of Miss Davis. I was unable to get in touch with Mrs. Campbell, but I was informed by the Rev. Father Chagnon, Principal of the Sandy Bay Indian Boarding School, that Mrs. Campbell would take this school.

She taught this school some ten years ago, and was satisfactory, and the Rev. Father Chagnon recommends her for the position. I have had no time to get applications or recommendations as I want a teacher there by the first of March, as once the school is closed it is hard to get the children started again.

Laura Shannon taught this school from January 1909 to June 1913.

On receipt of this letter kindly inform me by wire if I may appoint Mrs Campbell teacher of the Ebb and Flow School.

Your obedient servant,

Jerry Houle is a man with a large family.

At about this time a public health nurse let it be known to certain parties that I was to be dismissed from my post.

After my dismissal I wrote to Mr. Ward, M.P. He defended his action and from what he told me I could not blame him in the slightest for what occurred. I answered his letter in detail and here is an extract from his reply:

House of Commons, Canada, Ottawa, March 30, 1928.

Dear Mr. Taggart:

Acknowledging receipt of your interesting letter of the 26th instant, in further reference to the Ebb and Flow Indian School, and what I now believe to be, the unfair removal of yourself.

.............. and if you will drop me a line .... and let me know where I can meet you in Winnipeg, I will make every effort to meet your convenience, and looking forward with much interest to seeing you, and with kind regards, I remain, Yours very truly,

W. J. WARD, M.P.

When Mr. Ward met me in Winnipeg he had called upon Mr. Waite, Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie. As many things he said to me were in confidence, I am not free to say much. I can say, however, that Mr. Ward was fully convinced that a grave injustice had been done to me and expressed his sincere regrets at his part in the matter.

Since leaving the Ebb and Flow Indian School I have not been able to obtain any other employment. The fact that I was dismissed is itself against me and eight years' experience as a missionary teacher is not deemed of much value by commercial employers.

My dismissal has resulted in my utter destitution and I have been forced on to the relief rolls. I don't belong there and have done nothing to deserve this.

I respectfully request that the Department consider my case, and if I cannot be reinstated to my former position that I be given some other employment in the Government service.

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) A. G. Taggart,

Copies of correspondence and radio messages in connection with the dismissal of A. G. Taggart from the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School, Reedy Creek, Manitoba - Portage la Prairie Agency.

1. I was dismissed from the above mentioned school following representations made to the Department by W. J. WARD, Esq., M.P., of Dauphin. Mr. Ward acted upon complaints originating from the district of Ste. Rose du Lac, Man. The reason underlying these complaints was not, as represented, lack of interest on my part in the welfare of the Indians, but rather the manner in which I fought for improvement in the treatment of the half-breeds. In the winter of 1936-37 conditions were so bad that it was necessary to place almost the whole Reserve on rations. The half-breeds were in just as great need. On account of the urgency of cases it was necessary to use radio as the means of communication with the Provincial Government. Ebb and Flow being twenty miles from the railroad and with only two mails per week correspondence would have been too slow, as families were in grievous want. My persistence was represented by certain persons in the Manitoba Civil Service and there is no doubt that this influenced Mr. McCarthy, M.L.A., in persuading Mr. Ward that I should be removed. The charges made against me were without foundation. Had I not been interested in Indian welfare I would not have jeopardized my position thus, and I had been warned.

Here follow specimens of radiograms which caused the trouble:
(The following message was sent over my amateur station on a Saturday when I could not reach a Government office)

Signed A. G. Taggart, Teacher,

The records indicate that Mr. A. G. Taggart was employed by the Department as teacher at the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School during the period September 8, 1929, to June 30, 1937.

It was the Agent's opinion that a certain amount of dissatisfaction existed with respect to Mr. Taggart's work as dispenser of medicine. In view of the Agent's report, it was not considered advisable at that time to remove him from the school.

In a letter dated May 6, 1937, Mr. W. J. Ward, M.P., Dauphin, Manitoba, intimated that "I am convinced from information that I have received that the petition..."

Mr. Ward was informed that, in view of the agent's report and recommendation, it was not the intention of the Department to remove Mr. Taggart from the Ebb and Flow School.

Mr. Dane MacCarthy, Ste. Rose du Lac, Man., in a letter dated June 10, 1937, stated that a feeling of dissatisfaction with the work of the teacher of the Ebb and Flow School had existed on the reserve for a considerable period of time and that the matter had been brought to his attention two years previously. He expressed the view that Mr. Taggart should be removed from the school. A copy of Mr. MacCarthy's letter was sent forward to Mr. Waite by the Department, in a communication dated June 15, 1937. Mr. Waite was asked to again visit the Ebb and Flow School and to again report to the Department on the work of the teacher. On June 14, Mr. Ward again wrote to the Department. In that letter he stated: "I feel sure that I would not be receiving the number of letters I have from white residents living in the vicinity of the reserve, asking for the removal of Mr. Taggart, if there were not good and sufficient reasons why he should be removed".

The Indian agent's second report to the Department is dated August 2, 1937. In this report he states: "During treaty payments I held a meeting of the Indians and Mr. Taggart's position was discussed by the Indians in the teacher's presence. The chief complaints were the issuing of drugs, visiting the sick, the time he spent at his radio set and the issuing of rations. There was no specific complaint regarding Mr. Taggart's teaching ability". The agent concludes: "My personal opinion is that Mr. Taggart should be removed for his own good. He admitted living on bread and tea for some months. He is in receipt of a good salary from the

Department
Department and this poor living condition is unnecessary and points to one obvious fact, that this man is 'bushed' and, if allowed to stay, will drop to the level of the Indians themselves.

Immediately following receipt of the agent's second report, Mr. Taggart's case was very carefully and sympathetically reviewed by the officials. Mr. Taggart had been nominated for the position by Archbishop Sinnott, of Winnipeg. In view of this fact, a letter dated August 6, 1937, containing a summary of the agent's report, was sent to the Archbishop. The Archbishop, in his reply dated August 12, 1937, stated: "I am in receipt of your letter with reference to the teacher of the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School. I have to go north to Churchill and Chesterfield Inlet and will be away until the end of August. On my return I shall find a teacher whom I will recommend to you to replace Mr. Taggart. I hope the delay will not cause any inconvenience". The Archbishop later, in a letter dated August 27, 1937, nominated Mrs. Hilda Mary Adam for the vacant position. Mrs. Adam has a permanent second class teacher's certificate, valid in the province of Manitoba. Mrs. Adam was appointed on the understanding that the appointment was a temporary one and that her work would be carefully reviewed at the end of the year. Mrs. Adam's work at the school appears to be satisfactory.

It would appear that, for some reason, not explained in the correspondence, Mr. Taggart became interested in the half-breed population in the district and in the relief allowances granted these half-breeds by the Provincial Government. This action on his part appears to have brought him into direct conflict with the local member and later with the federal member for the district. In addition to this, Mr. Taggart aroused a great deal of criticism because of his tendency to operate his radio set, during school hours. His justification for this was that -
was that his house, attached to the school, was a stopping place for people visiting the reserve and that the radio was operated for their enjoyment.

A careful study of this case convinces one, however, that this teacher was, in the language of the Agent, actually 'bushed', that he had aroused the ill will and antagonism of the Indians and had ceased to be an uplifting influence on the reserve, either as a teacher or as a citizen.

Director.
