The average attendance is quite good, ranging around 18. The children are making fair progress, and I consider Mrs. Adam a capable teacher. She appears to understand Indian children and presents the work in a bright, cheerful manner. The children write well and the exercise books were neatly kept and showed careful work.

The children were clean and fairly well clothed. However, in the real severe weather no doubt lack of real warm clothing affects the attendance somewhat.

The living quarters for the teacher consists of two small rooms on the rear of the school, which accommodation I consider inadequate. One room is used as kitchen, dining-room and dispensary, and the other is the bedroom and storeroom. In the 1940-41 estimates the Agent inserted the amount of $692.00 covering the cost of two additional rooms and paint for the entire building. I am quite aware the list is too high, however, considering the funds are available I would suggest the material be purchased before March 31st and provision made for the labor to be carried out next summer. I would further point out that the building presents a very neglected appearance. The siding is dried and warped and the original paint has entirely disappeared. Regardless of the action is taken concerning immediate living accommodation, at least paint should be provided for the present building. If this were purchased and on hand it might be possible with Indian labor to do the painting before March 31st, which labor would not involve any great expense.

Ebb and Flow Lake Day School,
October 15, 1945.

Dear Sir:

I have received and studied your income tax papers and from them it looks as if I were single and without dependents. From Item 7, Form T.D.1, those in that state are advised not to file this form.

In reality, I have not dependents to claim as in those forms. But from another side, I have others to whom I owe great obligations. I am greatly obliged to those who has pushed me school for so many years. Now that I don't need to be helped much more, I have to help my father who has a large family of dependents and who depends from a land which has gone into deep debt instead of yielding good crops these last years. If somebody doesn't help him, I do not know how he will manage to live from nothing and having to pay at the same time store bills, fuel bills, lumberyard bills and a mortgage of a few thousands dollars on his land.
There are expenses in store for a new cellar under the house and a new barn.

Besides I have to reserve something for a career next year. Here food is pretty dear and it costs quite much for travelling. So this is why I have chosen the job that pays the most. It is to block the greatest number of holes possible. It is not because it is very interesting to live alone, in a dreary far-away country.

I slept returning money for my living expenses and future indebtedness. I will return my pay to my father as soon as received.

Sincerely Yours,

Joseph Marie Fontaine

Dear Mr. Pelletier:

I have for answer your letter of June 12 which was on my desk when I returned from an inspection trip to our schools in Quebec.

If you will refer to the Indian Act, you will find clearly outlined the procedure to be followed with regard to boys who are given leave of absence by the Indian Superintendent. They are not to be shown as discharged.

Our teachers were given an increase in salary before other Civil Servants two years ago. In other words, our salary adjustment of 1 September, 1948, was actually equivalent to the cost-of-living adjustment received by other Civil Servants in October, 1948.

If you will refer to the June issue of the Bulletin, you will find that a revised salary schedule is anticipated by 1 September, 1949.

If you will refer to our salary schedule, you will also find that the Department pays good salaries to teachers but expects them to be qualified. This is in accordance with the recommendation of the Indian Affairs Committee that teachers in our Indian Day Schools should be certificated. You will find that your attendance at normal school next year will result in a very marked increase in your salary.
Having taught in an Indian Day School much more isolated than that in which you are now located, you can rest assured I fully appreciate your difficulties.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 22nd. instant, and further to my letter of the 13th. idem, I wish to advise that the children from the settlement immediately south of the Ebb and Flow Reserve are half-breeds.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent.

Ottawa.
Ottawa,
EX'D April 29, 1938.

Dear Sir:

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 25th instant I consider that you should communicate with the Department of Education for the Province of Manitoba with a view to having them contribute toward the cost of the education of half breeds who are attending the Ebb and Flow School. As you are aware this Department is not responsible for the education of half breeds. We have no objection to their attending the Ebb and Flow School provided they do not occupy space that is required for the Indian children. At the same time it is considered that the Provincial Department of Education should contribute toward the cost of their education.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Ward:

Your letter of July 25, addressed to Mr. Christianson, has been brought to my attention.

We have not yet received any report from the Agent regarding the painting of the Ebb and Flow Indian Day School and it is doubtful if we will have any funds available for the purpose this year. However, if it is later decided to paint this building your recommendation of Mr. Sarto Guyot will be kept in mind.

Yours very truly,

Acting Director.

W. J. Ward, Esq., M. P.,
Dauphin, Man.
DAUPHIN, July 23rd, 1938.

Attention Mr. Christianson,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Booth Building,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I understand that your Provincial agent has recommended that the Ebb and Flow Indian school, Manitoba, should be painted, and it certainly needs painting. No doubt, if your Department has not already received several applications, you will, for this work.

The purpose of this letter is to recommend to you one Sarto Guyot, who is an experienced painter; in fact he is one of the few experienced painters available in that district. I know the personnel of the Ste Rose-Lake Manitoba district very well; know practically every adult person, and can say personally that Sarto Guyot is one of the very few experienced painters and one of the most reliable men in the district.

Yours sincerely,

WJW/RF.

W. J. Ward, M.P.
August 3rd 1938.

Dear Mr. Ward,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of July 23rd addressed to Mr. Christianson in connection with the painting of the Ebb and Flow Indian Day school.

Your letter has been forwarded to the Deputy Minister for direction.

Yours very truly,

Acting Director.

W. J. Ward, Esq., M.P.,
Dauphin, Man.

I beg to enclose herewith a report on the Ebb and Flow Day School, and also bring to your attention the condition of the walls and ceiling, which are very dirty. This school was built in the year 1927 and nothing has been done to the walls since. I am asking for a price on the cleaning and kalsomining of the walls and ceiling, and as soon as this is received a further report will be forwarded. An amount of $60.00 was placed in Estimates 1934-35 for this purpose. The seats are in a shaky state and I have also asked for an estimate to fix same. I have also asked for a price for the building of a teacher's toilet, this was not asked for in this year's estimates, but an amount for fencing was asked for and if the amount asked for for the fencing is approved, I believe a toilet could be built in addition to the fence. A further report will be forwarded in connection with this matter.

I also beg to advise that there are no scales on this reserve for the issuing of rations. These were not asked for in last year's estimates, although they have been asked for in previous Estimates. It is difficult to issue rations without a scale and leads to a certain amount of misunderstanding between the teacher, who is the issuer and the Indians.

I believe it could be arranged with the church authorities to fence the school and church on a 50-50 basis, as both buildings are close together and one enclosure would do for both.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Taggart, Teacher, Ebb and Flow Lake Day School, in which he asks for kalsomine for the renovating of the school room, which is badly needed, also repairs on school desks, and the erecting of a plate around the chimney. This matter was taken up with the Department in my report of May 31st, File No. 10.

The approximate cost of material for the renovating of the school room is as follows:
- Kalsomine 6 - 5 lb packages $3.60
- Sizing $.60
- Labour $13.00 Total $16.60

The cost of freighting will be extra.

The material and cost of building a toilet for the teacher:
- Materials $20.00
- Labour $3.00 Total $23.00

Stove bolts are required for repairing the desks about 10 dozen being required of assorted sizes. The labour will cost $3.00.

The iron plate around the stove pipe next to the chimney is very necessary and will cost in the neighbourhood of $7.00, including material and labour of fitting.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

Sir,

Re: 126-4-5

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 24th., file above noted, and wish to advise that the approximate cost of the listed material is $35.00.

This material is required to make an additional room in the attic of the living quarters. The school and teacher's quarters are combined, the teacher's quarters consisting of two small rooms, kitchen and bedroom.

The addition of the extra room in the attic will allow a sitting room downstairs and also room for officials when visiting the reserve.

I beg to recommend these purchases.
